column6: The Rare Earth Metal Driving Tensions Between the US and China - WIRED
column8: \"Yttrium plays a critical role in everything from aircraft engines to semiconductors. China controls the vast majority of the market—and that’s not changing anytime soon.\n\nThe alarm hasn't yet reached the general public
column9: but tension is beginning to build in the corridors of the aerospace industry
column11: and in government offices. For months
column12: an element almost invisible to the world—yttrium—has become the silent center of a new global dispute. Supplies are thinning
column14: deliveries are stalling. And while China and the United States have [promised a truce over rare earth minerals]( the wheels of advanced technology are beginning to slow.\n\nAlthough a late-October meeting in South Korea between Chinese president Xi Jinping and his US counterpart Donald Trump raised hopes for a détente
column15: the [Chinese export restrictions]( introduced last April remain substantially in place. Beijing granted a one-year reprieve on the mandatory government licensing system for shipments of rare earths and products containing related materials (including those made abroad with at least 0.1 percent Chinese resources)
column16: in exchange for a similar suspension of the White House's latest restrictions on technology supply chains.\n\nBut other measures introduced before the latest escalation remain in place. The result is a tightening of the international supply chain that threatens to slow advanced technological production
column18: and challenge entire industrial sectors. Yttrium plays a crucial role in the functioning of contemporary technologies. Without yttrium
column22: and semiconductors would immediately slow down.\n\nYttrium's value lies in its ability to impart thermal and mechanical strength to materials subjected to extreme temperatures. Jet engines blades
column24: must withstand prolonged overheating and intense vibration; yttrium is what allows them to maintain structural integrity and efficiency. The same is true for industrial chip manufacturing
column25: where yttrium-based coatings protect machinery from chemical wear and ensure precision in plasma etching. Its indispensable nature has made it a key element of modern technology and the military.\n\nThe problem is that
column27: China controls almost the entire global yttrium supply chain. Not only does it produce most of it
column28: but it also has the know-how and infrastructure to refine and separate it from other rare earth minerals
column29: a complex and technologically advanced process. According to US data
column30: the United States imports 100 percent of its yttrium needs
column31: 93 percent of which comes directly from China. Such stark dependence creates enormous geopolitical vulnerability.\n\nWhen Beijing decided to introduce export restrictions as a response to US tariffs
column32: the entire international supply structure began to falter. Companies reported delays
column34: and uncertainty about delivery times. In the rare earths trade
column35: lack of predictability is often more damaging than reduced volumes: An industry accustomed to just-in-time deliveries can be thrown into crisis by even a few weeks of delay.\n\nThe effects were immediate. In Europe
column38: 400 percent increase since the beginning of the year. Aerospace companies
column39: which rely heavily on this material
column40: have expressed alarm and demanded urgent measures from the US government to expand domestic production. The semiconductor industry is no less concerned: Some companies have called the situation a “serious” threat
column43: and production timelines. Gas-fired power plants
column44: which use yttrium in the protective coatings of turbines
column45: are also monitoring Chinese developments with increasing attention
column46: although they maintain that they have not yet experienced disruptions.\n\nThe situation in warehouses outside China adds further layers of complexity. Available reserves
column49: depending on the producers. Some traders have already reported running out of material; from quantities in the hundreds of tons range
column50: many are down to just a few units. Others are completely out of stock. This volatility makes the market extremely fragile and underscores how the global supply chain depends on a small number of players.\n\nChinese exports to several countries have fallen by about 30 percent. China
column51: which aims to become an autonomous tech powerhouse
column52: therefore maintains a position of strength and a high degree of discretion
column53: carefully regulating the quantities released to the international market. Moreover
column54: the measures introduced by Beijing in the sector from the outset are flexible enough to allow it to modulate the flow of shipments according to political priorities.\n\nOn the political front
column55: the trade truce between Washington and Beijing has yet to produce concrete results. The two sides have given negotiators until the end of November to outline clearer terms for rare earth exports to the United States
column56: but the gap between their respective priorities remains wide. Beijing continues to work on a licensing system
column57: inspired by mechanisms already used by the United States
column58: that would allow for faster flow only to companies deemed to have no ties to the US military industry. This would leave many Western companies operating in the delicate boundary between civilian production and defense applications at a disadvantage
column59: further complicating access to materials.\n\nChina's strategy involves not only controlling trade flows
column60: but also managing technical expertise internationally. Authorities have begun requiring detailed lists of technicians specializing in rare earths
column61: restricting their travel abroad and monitoring potential transfers of expertise to rival countries. At the same time
column62: bans on the export of advanced rare earth processing technologies continue
column63: a sector in which China holds a leadership position that is unlikely to be replicated in the short term. This dual approach—control of physical resources and human capital—strengthens Chinese primacy and hampers attempts to build an alternative supply chain.\n\nThe United States is nevertheless trying to fight back. New industrial projects
column64: such as that of ReElement Technologies in Indiana
column65: aim to produce yttrium oxide domestically starting in December
column66: with an initial capacity of 200 tons per year
column67: set to double within a few months. While this figure isn't enough to cover total US needs
column68: it represents a first step toward diversification.\n\nDuring Trump's recent visit to Asia
column69: Japan and the United States signed an agreement to jointly exploit the giant Minamitori undersea deposit
column70: discovered years ago in the Pacific seabed. Washington and Tokyo announced the launch of a joint study to develop technologies and infrastructure capable of extracting these strategic materials from extreme ocean depths
column71: a feat that will require enormous investment and advanced technical cooperation.\n\nYet the absence of a complete supply chain—from extraction to refining—makes the transition slow and complex. China has no intention of giving up its dominant position
column72:
a crucial and potentially decisive negotiating lever.

column84: \"Australian miners thrust into spotlight as yttrium rockets 4
column87: \"There’s a village on the Swedish island of [Resarö]( in the Stockholm archipelago with residential streets named after chemical elements
column90: and Tantalum Road.\n\nThe streets may seem quiet and unassuming yet this village
column92: is one of the most important places in scientific history – it’s regarded as the single richest source of elemental discoveries in the world. [Yttrium]( (Y)
column95: and [ytterbium]( (Yb) are all named after the village.\n\nOther elements including holmium
column99: and thulium were first discovered there
column100: making Ytterby the richest source of naturally occurring elements on Earth.\n\nBack in 1787
column101: army lieutenant and part-time chemist Carl Axel Arrhenius discovered a strange
column102: unusually heavy black ore in an old quarry near Ytterby. This new ore was named by Arrhenius as ytterbite.\n\nTwo years later
column103: a Finnish chemist identified from Arrhenius’ initial sample the first rare earth element – named yttrium. In just over 50 years following Arrhenius’ original discovery
column104: Carl Gustav Mosander found that ytterbite was actually a mixture of three metal oxides
column105: and a fourth was later discovered by Jean Charles Galissard de Marignac from the original sample.\n\nEventually as refining techniques improved
column106: more new elements were discovered and ultimately over the next 100 years since Arrhenius’ discovery
column107: nine more elements fell out of this strange
column108: unusually heavy black ore.\n\nAmong these hard-to-pronounce elements is yttrium – a soft
column109: grey-white metal that is fairly stable in air but reacts with water
column111: and bases.\n\nIt occurs in other ‘rare earth’ minerals
column114: which is mined in China and Malaysia
column115: can contain up to 50% yttrium phosphate
column116: according to the Royal Society of Chemistry.\n\nYttrium metal is produced by reducing yttrium fluoride with calcium metal and is often used as an additive in alloys for its strengthening properties. When alloyed with aluminum
column119: it acts to strengthen those metals.\n\nIn addition to its applications in speciality alloys found in engines
column120: yttrium is used in coatings to shield against high temperatures.\n\nYttrium oxide is added to glass used to produce camera lenses as it makes them heat and shock resistant. It’s found in white LED lights as well as superconductors and lasers
column121: with yttrium oxysulfide widely sought to produce red phosphors for old-style colour television tubes.\n\nLasers that can cut through metals require yttrium-aluminium garnet (YAG)
column122: marking yet another of its many applications in everyday life.\n\nWhile its origins may come from Sweden
column123: like other rare earths and critical minerals
column124: China dominates global production and supply of yttrium. China supplies the US 93% of its yttrium imports
column125: creating acute vulnerability across Western supply chains.\n\nThe world’s supplies are now running low due to Chinese export restrictions
column126: sparking fears of looming protracted shortages
column127: and rocketing costs that could hit every sector from aerospace
column128: to energy and semiconductor production.\n\nOn the back of China restricting yttrium exports (along with six other rare earths in April in retaliation to the US tariffs) yttrium oxide (Y₂O₃) prices have been soaring more than 4
column131: as China’s tightening export controls disrupt global supply chains for military and defence
column134: and advanced materials. These shortages are also affecting markets related to high-temperature alloys
column137: and defence components.\n\nMagnet rare earth prices also remain high
column138: with Benchmark reporting Dy oxide (DDP China) at over US$200/kg and Tb oxide (DDP China) at almost US$1
column139:
000/kg.

[Victory Metals]( (ASX:VTM) CEO Brendan Clark says this global backdrop highlights the company’s strategic positioning as a major future yttrium supplier with what’s emerging as a valuable heavy rare earth basket.

The company’s current mineral resource hosts over 35 million kilograms of Y₂O₃ with forecast production targets over 600 tonnes annually tonnes along with strategic critical minerals dysprosium
column144:
and scandium.

Clark says yttrium is emerging as one of the world’s most important critical minerals and this global supply crunch is happening much faster than anyone expected.

*“Our North Stanmore deposit continues to demonstrate the scale
column146: and mineralogy required to supply Western nations with secure
column148: ”* the CEO adds.\n\nVictory is now advancing discussions with multiple strategic partners across the defence
column151: and semiconductor sectors seeking secure non-Chinese heavy rare earth supply.\n\nClark says the surge in yttrium pricing materially enhances Victory’s Prefeasibility Study (PFS)
column152: with the company continuing to integrate high value heavy rare earths including yttrium
column155: and recently confirmed gallium into its economic modelling.\n\nThe CEO recently told shareholders at the company’s AGM that China’s moves to ban the export of key defence-related minerals such as terbium
column156: dysprosium and scandium is an opportunity for Victory Metals to demonstrate its capability to produce these critical materials at scale and to help Australia become a key player in the global energy transition.\n\n*“We expect the PFS will define the processing pathway
column158: and production strategy for the North Stanmore project
column159: and demonstrate how the underlying resources can be turned into a commercial
column161: ”* Clark says.\n\nClark notes an exhaustive PFS into Victory’s flagship North Stanmore Project
column162: near Cue in Western Australia’s Mid West region
column163: continues to indicate the project’s potential as one of the most advanced heavy rare earth clay-hosted deposits.\n\n> ***“We are confident we can deliver significant grade increases in terbium
column164: dysprosium and scandium – three of the world’s most valuable and strategically critical elements”***\n\n*“Indications are we can avoid complex cracking or additional capital-intensive processing and environmental impacts
column165: which further strengthens our value as a secure
column166: reliable and capable potential supplier of high-purity feedstock to global processors
column167: ”* the CEO adds.\n\n*“With minimal processing under our proposed operating model

column171: and significant interest from government and private sector defence manufacturers around the world seeking secure off-take agreements.\n\nIn August 2025

column174: Victory signed a non-binding LoI with Japanese trading house Sumitomo Corporation to advance offtake and strategic cooperation for North Stanmore
column175: covering up to 30% of annual production

including up to 50 tonnes of Dy-Tb product over an initial five-year term.

The Export-Import Bank has also offered an LoI regarding funding support of US$190 million.

Victory Metals is among a number of Australian rare earths explorers thrust into the global spotlight
column177: following the landmark agreement between US President Donald Trump and Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese to facilitate the investment of the billions of dollars needed to establish secure and reliable rare earth and critical minerals supply chains.\n\nWith the state of the market
column178: [ABx Group]( (ASX:ABX) has also been ramping up efforts to become a significant player in rare earths space. It’s been raising $6.05 million through a placement to fund development activities at the Deep Leads Project in Tasmania and construction of the ALCORE pilot plant.\n\nFunds will be deployed to engineering and metallurgical studies
column179: exploration drilling for a resource increase

and to secure offtake agreements for the Deep Leads Project.

Proceeds will also cover construction and commissioning costs of the ALCORE pilot plant to produce hydrogen and fluoride from aluminium smelter bath waste.

The Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation ([ANSTO]( has started production of ABx’s first mixed rare earth carbonate (MREC) product using 50kg of a 100kg bulk sample
column181:
with completion expected before the end of November 2025.

The sample will be distributed to potential customers and offtake partners for evaluation.

ABx is running a program to produce a saleable MREC product from its Deep Leads ionic adsorption clay rare earth project in Tasmania to be used in downstream refining to produce separated rare earth oxides
column183: and magnets essential for EV motors
column186: and other clean-energy technologies.\n\nRare earth refineries (solvent-extraction plants) commonly accept MREC because it’s a standardised
column187: transportable feedstock from which high-purity rare earth oxides and metals can be produced.\n\nIn partnership with external engineering experts
column188: ABx conducted a formal processing options analysis. A key conclusion is that column leach tests should be conducted to confirm that the high extractions obtained in diagnostic leach tests in tanks are also observed in a column leach arrangement.\n\nANSTO is conducting initial column leach tests planned to begin in November
column189: with results available by early 2026.\n\nManaging Director of emerging rare earths producer [OD6 Metals]( (ASX:OD6)
column191: believes there is plenty of opportunity for Western countries like Australia to capture a substantial share of the burgeoning market dominated by China.\n\nRecently speaking to *Mining.com.au*

column193: which reshaping how government and private partnerships can work in an investor scheme to bolster Western supply chains.\n\nIf the Western world does not want all roads leading to China
column194: Hazelden argues they need to obviously pay a fair price that allows people to make money but also allows them to participate in the next part of the value chain as well.\n\nThe make-up of OD6’s Splinter Rock Rare Earth Elements Project in Western Australia opens up a plethora of potential end-user avenues for the minnow. The emerging rare earths producer has proven it can produce a clean
column196: which is a product highly sought after by several end users.\n\nOD6 has now identified another avenue for consideration down the track for the production of samarium and yttrium oxides
column197: which are both used in nuclear reactors for clean power generation and nuclear medicine.\n\nSamarium is also used in the manufacture of high-temperature samarium-cobalt magnets for headphones
column198: electric motors and aerospace applications.\n\nIn early October
column199: OD6 elected a preferred [flowsheet]( with the aim of producing MREC and mixed rare earth hydroxide (MREH). Flowsheet testing undertaken by ANSTO achieved a MREC recovery of about 56% total rare earth oxide (TREO)
column200: and a MREH recovery of roughly 59% TREO.\n\nThe process demonstrated low levels of aluminium
column203: and extremely low uranium and thorium content of less than 0.001%. Overall recoveries of the most in-demand magnet rare earths
column205: reached around 75% for OD6.\n\nThe high value magnet rare earths account for 23% of the TREO grade at Splinter Rock
column206: which hosts a resource so far of 682 million tonnes @ 1

column215: Foreign media on Kazakhstan: Kazakhstan enters global rare earth metals arena; How Kazakhstan’s female entrepreneurs leading Central Asia’s tech revolution - Qazinform
column217: \"# Foreign media on Kazakhstan: Kazakhstan enters global rare earth metals arena; How Kazakhstan’s female entrepreneurs leading Central Asia’s tech revolution\n\nBased on recent developments
column218: including Kazakhstan’s deepening cooperation with Turkmenistan as the presidents of both countries conclude high level talks in Astana
column219: the country’s growing entry into the global rare earth metals market
column220: and the rise of Kazakh female entrepreneurs driving Central Asia’s tech transformation
column221: [Qazinform News Agency]( presents a weekly review of foreign media coverage.\n\nAfter wrapping up high-level talks in Astana
column222: Presidents Kassym-Jomart Tokayev of Kazakhstan and Serdar Berdimuhamedov of Turkmenistan came together to sign a Joint Statement focused on boosting their bilateral relations
column223:
[Trend.az]( reports.

Among the key agreements was a Joint Action Plan for Transport Cooperation between the two countries for 2026-2027.

Moreover
column224: the officials from both countries shook hands and put pen to paper on agreements that span a broad spectrum of sectors
column228:
the sides agreed on enhanced pension system cooperation and signed a memorandum to advance veterinary services and agricultural research.

Kazakhstan’s National Academy of Sciences and Turkmenistan’s Academy of Sciences also agreed to increase research collaboration.

According to [The Times of Central Asia]( Kazakhstan
column229: long recognized for its substantial rare earth metals reserves
column230: is moving beyond the familiar characterization of “underutilized potential” and is taking on a more active role in global critical material supply chains. The state-owned mining company Tau-Ken Samruk has become a key driver of this shift
column231: expanding both at home and abroad.\n\nKazakhstan recently confirmed a new deposit with major reserves of cerium
column235: strengthening its position as one of the few countries producing more than half of the known rare earth elements. The national strategy now centers on developing a full industrial cycle rather than exporting raw materials.\n\nA clear example of this change came in 2025
column236: when Tau-Ken Samruk signed an agreement with U.S. based Cove Capital to develop the Severny Katpar and Verkhniy Kairakty tungsten deposits. A similar project with China’s Xiamen Tungsten collapsed in 2018 without binding commitments
column237: highlighting growing geopolitical competition around Kazakhstan’s resources.\n\nThe country is also expanding internationally. According to Samruk-Kazyna chairman Nurlan Zhakupov
column238: Kazakhstan aims to process materials from both domestic and foreign sources. “Tau-Ken Samruk is actively engaging with foreign partners
column240: noting exploration projects underway in Rwanda and Afghanistan.\n\nThese efforts illustrate Kazakhstan’s ambition to secure a larger role in global supply chains. Despite political and security risks abroad
column241: the country continues to pursue long-term partnerships and deeper integration into the rare earth market.\n\nWomen in Kazakhstan are reshaping the tech landscape
column242: entering the sector from diverse backgrounds and driving new forms of innovation
column243: [Euronews]( reports.\n\nA key figure in this movement is Assem Bolatzhan
column244: who shifted from finance to IT in 2015 through the Digital Kazakhstan program.\n\n“We launched the Women in Tech chapter in Kazakhstan because we need to be part of a global community
column245: ” she says.\n\nAccording to Women in Tech Astana lead Rinata Ilyubayeva
column246: nearly 60% of women-led startups focus on social impact.\n\n“Most female startups are in EdTech
column248: and solutions for children with autism
column251:
” she notes.

The momentum has led to the creation of Central Asia’s first female-focused venture capital initiative.

“We are building a platform to support women
column253:
” says Ilyubayeva.

Entrepreneurs like Aigerim Nurgaliyeva show how women without technical training can succeed.

“The first obstacle was in my mind
column254: ” she says. “You can build a startup without coding.”\n\nSCAT Airlines (DV
column255: Shymkent) is considering adding either B777 or B787 aircraft to its fleet for deliveries after 2030
column257: citing senior marketing manager Zhanar Balgabay.\n\nAccording to [ch-aviation]( data
column258: the Kazakh airline currently has commitments for seven more B737-8s and one additional B737-9.\n\nIts in-house fleet comprises one B737-300
column266: three B757-200s and one B767-300ER are operated by subsidiary Sunday Airlines (Shymkent)
column267: which deploys the aircraft on charter services to destinations including Phuket
column272: SCAT Airlines has firmed plans to launch flights from Turkistan to Urgench
column274: and Samarkand by December 2025. The carrier currently serves 40 destinations across 16 countries
column275: operating a total of 61 routes.\n\nKazakhstan wins second straight Asia Championship with win over Japan
column276: Korea beats China to finish second\n\n**IIHF.com: Kazakhstan wins second straight Asia Championship with win over Japan
column277: Korea beats China to finish second**\n\nKazakhstan secured back-to-back titles at the IIHF Ice Hockey Men’s Asia Championship
column278: going undefeated in Beijing with a 3-0 record and a 13-6 goal ratio. Korea finished second
column280: [IIHF.com]( reports.\n\nIn the decisive match against Japan
column281: Roman Starchenko led Kazakhstan with two goals in the second period. After a 1-1 opening frame
column282: Kazakhstan surged ahead with three goals to take a 4-2 lead.\n\nJapan cut the deficit late in the third through Masato Okubo
column283: forcing a tense finish as coach Jarrod Skalde pulled the goalie for an extra attacker. Kazakh goaltender Roman Kalmykov delivered key saves
column284: including a breakaway stop on Kazumo Sasaki and a last second block on Okubo
column285: securing the win and the championship.\n\n[Foreign Mass Media about Kazakhstan]( [Kazakhstan]( [Turkmenistan]( [Central Asia]( [Hockey]( [Critical minerals](  [Tourism]( [Travel]( [Analytics](\"

Tomorrow’s market open promises to be a very interesting one for silver stocks after silver’s near 6% surge on Friday night post the ASX closing...

(hitting the highest price in its history and delivering a key breakout of a 50 year chart pattern we have been watching...)

Here are all the silver stocks we are Invested in and ones to watch on Monday morning
column292: click on the link to read out Investment thesis for each one:\n\n[SS1](/company/asx-ss1/)
column298:
[BKB](/company/asx-jby/) - also now joined by explorer [PFE](/company/asx-pfe/).

You can read in more detail on the significance silver’s Friday surge and technical breakout in our Saturday note:

In this note we also wrote about why we think there will be a rally in small ASX stocks into the Christmas break.

Below is a summary and links for **everything else** we wrote about last week
column299: along with some other interesting content we found in relation to our Portfolio.\n\n**LKY** appointed [**Lockheed Martin strategy and risk manager**](/quick-takes/lky-adds-lockheed-martin-exec-to-its-advisory-board/)
column301:
to its advisory board.

*Stacy joins ex-Major General Peter Lambert as appointments to LKY’s team - both with existing networks into the US military industrial complex.*

*LKY is also advancing a white paper for “critical minerals into defence pathways” under the Defense Production Act. (aka government funding prep work)*

**LKY** also kicked off pre-drilling work on its US rare earths project
column302:
and will follow that up with drilling of its antimony project. LKY is anticipating a ‘[**continuous flow of exploration news and data through Q1 and Q2 of 2026**](

**WCE** hit silver in [**5 out of 8 zones**](/quick-takes/wce-hits-visible-silver-at-the-elizabeth-hill-mine-in-wa/) from its latest diamond drillholes.

*The results were from handheld XRF readings - so we will need to wait for final assays from these holes (due in mid-December).*

**BPM** released an update on [**its rare earth project**](/quick-takes/bpm-samples-rare-earth-oxide-grades-up-to-965-in-wa/) in WA.

*Rock chips grading up to 9.65% TREO
column303: within a newly confirmed 5km of mineralised strike... but most importantly
column304:
the same type of rocks that Iluka is looking to feed through its WA refinery that is under construction.*

The bigger news from **BPM** this week was that it [**raised $3.5M to help expand and accelerate drilling**](/quick-takes/bpm-raises-funds-drilling-on-wa-gold-asset-to-start-in-few-days/) at its WA gold project (*which should start in the coming weeks*).

**ILA** was [**added to the Medical Countermeasures Coalition**](/quick-takes/ila-added-to-a-coalition-of-companies-which-includes-multi-billion-dollar-big-pharma-companies/) (MC2) to advance US procurement and stockpiling opportunities.

*Some interesting names make up that coalition
column305:
including a few who have a proven track record developing drugs that went onto get big US stockpiling deals.*

**PNN** announced [**results from a drill program**](/quick-takes/pnn-now-weeks-away-from-10000m-drill-program-on-brazilian-rare-earths-asset/) on its Brazilian rare earth project.

*The results were from a shallow auger program
column306: and delivered further high grade niobium and rare earths results...*\n\n*Next PNN will kick off the first phase of a 10
column307:
000m RC drill program (due to start in December) ahead of a “maiden resource in Q1-2026”.*

**SGQ** hit [**extensions to its already large rare earths resource**](/quick-takes/sgq-hits-extensions-to-the-biggest-rare-earths-resources-deposit-in-south-america/) in Brazil.

*SGQ has 3 rigs drilling 24/7
column308:
29 assays in the lab and 40 more holes planned... so we should see more good news like this week’s results over the coming weeks/months.*

**KAU** is looking at ways [**to get more feed**](/quick-takes/kau-to-drill-waste-dumps-next-to-victorian-processing-plant/) through its processing plant in Victoria...

*One of those had samples with grades of 0.86g/t
column309:
the other 1.8g/t... both very processable grades especially so close to KAU’s Victorian plant and an all time high gold price.*

**ION** raised $4.4M to “*Advance E-Waste Recycling Opportunities in the USA*”.

*We participated in ION’s capital raise - we especially liked that there was almost no discount to the market price AND the board participated in the round (both good signals for a capital raise).*

**LSR** started its [**first exploration program**](/quick-takes/lsr-starts-exploration-on-us-heavy-rare-earths-project/) on its project in Arizona.

*Previous sampling at LSR’s project showed 0.53-1.26% TREO
column310:
importantly with ~57% heavy rare earths (the valuable ones).*

*The big win for us will be if LSR can show those same grades are consistent across a bigger part of its project.*

**SS1** [**released another drill result**](/quick-takes/ss1-hits-silver-and-gold-26m-above-its-existing-480m-ounce-silver-equivalent-resource/) from its 2025 drill program.

*The kicker for us was that mineralisation in the assay results started a lot closer to surface compared to where SS1’s resource estimate begins.*

*Near surface results could be a game changer for SS1’s project
column311:
removing all of the risks related to pre-stripping a deep orebody (i.e. mining the waste rock above the existing resource).*

**HAR** [**completed its second round of drilling**](/quick-takes/har-completes-drilling-on-gold-project-assay-results-coming-next-month/) on its gold project in Senegal.

*HAR is following up the results from a few months ago including the 20m intercept grading 6.54g/t gold.*

*HAR is moving very quickly here (which always makes us pay a lot more attention) and has already committed to deeper RC/diamond drilling in early 2026.*

This week **HAR** also [**confirmed a drill rig is on site**](/quick-takes/har-to-start-drilling-on-us-gold-project-today/) at its US based gold project in California **AND that drilling was scheduled to have started on the night shift of Friday 28th November.**

The goal is to convert the current resource to JORC compliant
column312:
and HAR expects to complete this by late January 2026.

**TTM** [**released more drill results**](/quick-takes/ttm-results-set-to-add-to-resource-as-lingbao-prepares-for-another-visit/) from its 3.1Moz gold and 22Moz silver project in Ecuador.

*More interesting to us though was the confirmation
column313: strategic investor Lingbao was “preparing a second site visit” as part of its due diligence toward doing a potential project level transaction with TTM for the Dynasty Gold Project.*\n\n**88E** put out an [**update on its projects in Alaska**](/quick-takes/88e-to-flow-test-well-next-to-711m-neighbour/)
column314: USA.\n\n*88E is fully carried for all costs associated with an upcoming horizontal well and extended flow test. 88E’s farm in partner is Burgundy Xploration

who is gearing up for an IPO in the US to support operational spend.*

**MNB** provided an [**update for its Cabinda phosphate project**](/quick-takes/mnb-update-on-angolan-phosphate-project/) in Angola.

*IF the alternative structure can be pulled off
column316: MNB could be fast-tracking first production by simplifying its processing flowsheet
column319: and dust extraction to cut ~$20M in CAPEX and $17/t operating costs.*\n\n*There is a fair bit to go through the announcement - Long story short
column320:
there looks to be a delay in the first production date mentioned months ago.*

**TG1** [**identified unmapped historical workings**](/quick-takes/tg1-finds-unmapped-historic-workings-on-recently-acquired-project/) at its Dalgaranga Gold Project in WA.

*TG1’s new project sits in a relatively well understood part of WA so it was a surprise to find unmapped historic workings. - a small open pit mined at 2.5g/t gold and multiple shallow workings.*

*Usually these historic workings are found on remote sites - so we liked that announcement from TG1.*

**L1M** [**raised $2.5M to fund drilling**](/quick-takes/l1m-raises-25m-exploration-programs-to-start-early-next-year/) on its QLD and NSW assets.

*We participated in the raise and we are looking forward to Phase 2 of L1M drilling its Queensland gold asset
column321:
following up the encouraging mineralisation it hit during Phase 1 drilling in recent months.*

**EIQ** has developed (and is already in the market with) an AI-powered algorithm that helps cardiologists detect heart diseases.

EIQ’s tech is already USA FDA approved AND being used by a growing number of hospitals in the USA to detect one heart disease called Aortic Stenosis.

**Earlier this week EIQ announced results of a clinical validation study on a different heart disease - Heart Failure.**

Heart Failure is one of the big heart diseases - US$60BN is spent on it
column323:
and it's the leading cause of rehospitalisation.

EIQ’s clinical validation study was run by the prestigious Mayo Clinic. The study delivered exceptional results on **detecting heart failure with 99.5% sensitivity and 91.0% specificity** ([source](

Much better than the only other AI heart failure detection software used in the market today which delivers **sensitivity of 87.8% and specificity of 81.9%** ([source](

(Both technologies are a step change from current practices where only 50% of Heart Failure cases are accurately diagnosed.)

IF EIQ can get FDA approval for its Heart Failure AI model
column324:
there already exists a reimbursement code the company can use to commercialise its AI tech.

The reimbursement code exists thanks to Ultromics (who [raised US$55M]( in a series C funding round valuing them at US$300M / A$464M back in July).

Now we watch for FDA clearance...

**IIQ** is developing an exosome platform technology.

IIQ is applying its exosome platform to develop diagnostics (detecting diseases) AND therapeutics (treating diseases).

Exosomes are tiny
column325:
microscopic extra-cellular “containers” that carry ‘messages’ between the human body's cells that allows the human body to function.

**IIQ is going after two types of cancer that have NO approved/recommended treatments or diagnostic tools.**

* Ovarian cancer is usually asymptomatic (no symptoms) in the early stages of the disease. If a woman is diagnosed at stage 1 - the survival rates can be over 90%. If a woman is diagnosed at stages 3/4 survival rates can be ~29%. ~70% of all ovarian cancer in Australia is diagnosed as advanced [stage 3 or 4 cancer](

* At the moment there are no recommended screening tests for women who show no symptoms of ovarian cancer - meaning there is no quick and easy screening test that can be regularly taken by all healthy women to catch ovarian cancer early.

* **IIQ’s screening test has been able to detect all stage 1 and 2 ovarian cancers (the earliest but asymptomatic stages where survival rates are the highest)
column326:
with over 99.6% specificity (catching 99.6% of all patients with cancer) AND NO misdiagnosis.**

* **What’s Next:** IIQ to do a larger clinical validation study (to see if the test works on a larger cohort of patients) then look at “strategic partnering” to commercialise the screening tool.

* Triple negative breast cancer is an aggressive type of breast cancer that does NOT respond to traditional breast cancer therapies.

* At the moment
column327:
there are no approved cell therapies treating triple negative breast cancer.

* IIQ is developing the therapeutic under a deal signed with the prestigious Peter MacCallum Cancer Centre (Peter Mac) in Melbourne. The institution is among only a handful globally that combines a dedicated cancer hospital with a fully integrated cancer research program.

* **So far IIQ has shown that its therapeutic was able to kill more than 90% of the cancer cells within 10 hours of treatment in in vitro studies (in a laboratory setting).**

* **What’s next:** Next for the therapeutic is the results from animal studies (in-vivo) due this quarter.

We think that any solid tumour therapeutic IIQ is able to develop could be a game changer for the company.

Mainly because it would de-risk IIQ’s platform tech (if it works for one cancer

**EXR** is the biggest net acreage holder in the Taroom Trough - second only to supermajor $320BN Shell.

EXR just did a deal with the #3 landholder in the region - Omega Oil and Gas.

Omega took a 19.43% position in EXR in exchange for $13.9M at 4.1c per share.

Omega is backed by Tri-Star (pioneers of the Queensland gas industry) and it recently did a deal with ~$2.8BN Beach Energy.

After all is said and done EXR will have a $35.3M capital budget to work with.

AND next
column338:
EXR is drilling a vertical well targeting a ~1 trillion cubic feet of contingent gas resource (estimate).

Drilling starts in January...

And then a horizontal section
column339:
with stimulating and testing will follow straight after.

It all kicks off on the 12th of January according to the EXR MD and CEO Stuart Nicholls in a webinar a few days ago. ([Source - watch it here](

We also noticed that were two specific conditions as part of Omega’s investment in EXR.

First the “standstill” - which means Omega can’t buy any more shares in EXR for at least 12 months - basically EXR is given a 12-month period to deliver material catalysts (like the Lorelle drilling and horizontal well)...

And second
column340: the support condition - which basically means if EXR were to attract a takeover offer within the next 12 months from someone OTHER THAN Omega
column341: Omega wouldn't be able to block the transaction (UNLESS they are willing to match/beat the proposal).\n\nWe think this is a very good deal for EXR shareholders

column378: Victoria strengthens critical minerals capabilities with green light at Goschen - Australian Mining
column380: \"Victoria is continuing to deliver accelerated critical minerals capabilities thanks to an approved mining work plan for VHM’s Goschen rare earths and minerals sands project in the state’s northwest.\n\nThe work plan covers pre-production logistical considerations such as how to protect the local environment and community
column381: including requirements such as monitoring air quality data and publishing real-time dust level data online.\n\nLocated in Victoria’s premier mineral sands corridor
column382: the project is underpinned by a [199 million tonne proved and probable ore reserve]( and is understood to be scalable with a 629 million tonne mineral resource with “ongoing growth potential”.\n\nVictoria has been described as [possessing world-class mineral sand deposits]( containing demonstrated resources of titanium
column383: zirconium and rare earth elements. As such
column384: developing these is crucial to energy transition as it helps provide the materials needed for solar panels
column385: wind turbines and batteries.\n\nThe project is understood to boast over 400
column386: 000 tonnes of total rare earth oxide alongside a “world-class” mineral sands resource
column387: making it one of Australia’s most significant [critical minerals projects](\n\nNews of work plan approval comes after Victoria’s critical minerals future was advanced with the [approval of an exploration tunnel at the Sunday Creek]( antimony and gold projects
column388: highlighting a shift in focus from both mining companies and industry bodies.\n\nDescribed as one of Victoria’s “most significant mineral sands and rare earths projects”
column389: Victorian Energy Minister Lily D’Ambrosio noted the move goes beyond simply critical mineral capabilities across Victoria.\n\n“Critical minerals development in the Wimmera and Mallee could support up to 7
column390: 000 new jobs in the coming decades
column391: and we are backing local communities with these well-paying jobs
column392: ” she said.\n\nThe [approval]( forms part of the Labor government’s Critical Minerals Roadmap set out last year to unlock the state’s critical minerals potential.\"

column423: 2 Monster Stocks to Hold for the Next 5 Years - The Motley Fool
column425:
"* Multibagger stocks can grow your wealth exponentially.

* Niche players in high-potential industries can deliver monster returns over time.

* Robotics and rare earths are two such industries you'd want to look at right away.

These two stocks could skyrocket as they exploit their first-mover advantages in two massive industries.

Some stocks don't just outperform the broader markets -- they have the potential to deliver monumental returns over time
column426: supercharging your portfolio for years to come. They're not hard to find if you know where to look. Such stocks with [multibagger]( potential are often hidden among leaders in fast-growing industries
column427: first movers in industries with exponential potential
column428:
and innovative start-ups that are shaping the future.

Two such stocks have caught my attention. Each has such compelling growth prospects that buying them now and holding them could yield monster returns over the next five years or so.

Image source: Getty Images.

Rare-earth elements technically aren't rare
column429: but it's not easy to extract them in ways that are economically viable. China has a monopoly
column430: accounting for almost 70% of the global rare-earth extraction. That also means [80% of the rare-earth elements consumed in the U.S.]( are imported
column431: with nearly all of them coming from China.\n\nThat's not a great place to be. Rare-earth elements are vital for electronics
column438: China's dominance poses significant supply risks to the U.S. Additionally
column439: it has always disincentivized U.S. [mining]( companies from pouring money into rare-earth elements. President Donald Trump wants to change that and
column441: has allocated billions of dollars to critical mineral projects
column442: even buying stakes in some domestic producers to secure U.S. supply chains.\n\nThere is only one active rare-earth mine in the U.S.: the Mountain Pass in California
column443: owned and operated by **MP Materials** ([MP](/quote/nyse/mp/) +2.99%).\n\nIn July 2025
column445: rebranded as the Department of War (DOW) by Trump
column446: acquired a 15% stake in MP Materials and became its largest shareholder. MP Materials will build a rare-earth magnet manufacturing facility
column448:
with the DOW committing to purchase 100% of the rare-earth magnets produced at the facility for 10 years. Two of its other major deals include:

* A $500 million multiyear agreement with tech giant **Apple** ([AAPL](/quote/nasdaq/aapl/) +0.46%) to supply magnets.

* A partnership with the DOW and the Saudi Arabian Mining Company (Maaden) to develop a rare-earth refinery in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.

MP Materials currently produces rare-earth oxides and metals and will begin production of magnets by the end of 2025. [MP Materials stock already carries a market cap of $10 billion]( but that could look minuscule five years from now.

Shares of **Symbotic** ([SYM](/quote/nasdaq/sym/) 4.04%) have surged over 250% so far in 2025
column449: as of this writing. And there could be a lot more to come.\n\nSymbotic automates warehouses and distribution centers with [artificial intelligence (AI)]( [robotics]( that can move
column451: and sort items. Symbotic went public in 2022 but has been working with **Walmart** ([WMT](/quote/nyse/wmt/) +1.31%) since 2015 to deploy robotic systems at multiple distribution centers. In January 2025
column452: Symbotic acquired Walmart's advanced systems and robotics (ASR) business for automated fulfillment of orders
column453: a new product category for Symbotic.\n\nUnder yet another new and recent agreement
column454: Symbotic will develop and install automated micro-fulfillment systems for online pickup and delivery at Walmart's retail stores. Symbotic expects its first prototype to be ready in 2026. Meanwhile
column455: Symbotic is developing a next-generation storage technology as well. Besides Walmart
column459: and **Target**.\n\nSymbotic has also just announced something big: It has signed up Medline as a customer
column460: marking its foray into healthcare. [Medline is a major distributor of medical supplies]( in the U.S. and is expected to go public soon. Symbotic deployed its first system to Medline last quarter.\n\nSymbotic's entry into healthcare marks a significant milestone
column461: as it opens up a new vertical for the company beyond retail and could fast-track its sales growth. Symbotic just posted a 26% growth in revenue for the fiscal year that ended Sept. 27
column463: and projects similar growth for the first quarter of fiscal year 2026.\n\nMost importantly
column464: Symbotic ended the year with a backlog of $22.5 billion. That's huge
column465: as it represents nearly a decade's worth of sales. So
column466: even though Symbotic's market cap has surpassed $50 billion
column467: its estimated addressable market runs into the hundreds of billions of dollars
column468: making it a solid stock to own for the long term.\n\nBoth MP Materials and Symbotic share a common link -- they have the first-mover advantage in their respective industries
column469: *and* both industries have exponential growth potential. That's what makes these stocks so appealing. Growth stocks carry their share of risks
column470: but with both Symbotic and MP Materials already generating revenue and striking significant partnerships
column471: they're worth the risk.\n\nNeha Chamaria is a contributing Motley Fool stock market analyst covering energy
column475: with a focus on dividend stocks. Prior to The Motley Fool
column476: Neha worked on portfolio valuations for hedge funds at HSBC and authored articles as a journalist. She holds a master’s degree in finance from ICFAI and an MBA from Symbiosis University
column477: along with certifications from the National Stock Exchange of India. Neha was honored with an all-India gold medal for her M.S. in Finance and was the first woman in her family to pursue a professional career.\n\nInvest better with The Motley Fool. Get stock recommendations
column479: and more from The Motley Fool's premium services.\"
column481: One discovery that Oriented 2025: 12 Days of Christmas - Mining.com.au
column483: \"As the mining and resources industry winds down for the year and the festive season settles in
column485: exploring the forces shaping the sector.\n\nMuch like the classic carol
column486: each day builds on the last. On the first day we’re diving into one gift that set the tone of the year for critical minerals explorer [Iltani Resources]( (ASX:ILT).\n\nSince June 2023
column487: the company has focused exploration efforts at the Orient deposit near Herberton in Far North Queensland
column488: uncovering its prospectivity to produce silver
column492: Iltani’s efforts paid off when the company flagged the asset to potentially be one of the *“highest-grade known silver-indium”* deposits
column493: emerging as one of 2025’s brightest lights in critical minerals exploration
column494: as [reported]( by *Mining.com.au*.\n\nThe project comprises two main areas of focus – Orient East and Orient West – within the greater Herberton Project
column495: which spans around 367km2 in the Herberton Mineral Field.\n\nThe combined deposits have returned a maiden resource estimate of 62.5 million tonnes @ 81.5 grams per tonne silver-equivalent at a 30g/t cut-off grade
column496: with a higher grade core of 34.2 million tonnes @ 110.4g/t silver-equivalent with a 60g/t cut-off grade – the kind worth placing under any explorer’s Christmas tree.\n\nOrient East hosts a resource of 19.8 million tonnes @ 98g/t silver-equivalent
column497: with a higher grade core of 12.6 million tonnes @ 128g/t silver-equivalent
column498: as [reported](\n\nOn the return of recent versatile time domain electromagnetic (VTEM) target drilling at the project
column499: Iltani says Orient has demonstrated potential to materially increase the mineral resource.\n\n*Mining.com.au* [reports]( across a 10-hole shallow campaign
column500: the first hole (ORR128) delivered multiple intersections of *“thick”* silver-lead-zinc-indium mineralisation
column501: 450m north of the Orient East resource zone.\n\nMineralisation remains open along strike and down-dip
column502: which is believed to upgrade the resource substantially.\n\nIltani has received its final assay results from VTEM drilling
column503: such as 20m @ 93.8 grams per tonne silver-equivalent (AgEq) from 4m
column505: including 1m @ 279.3g/t AgEq from 171m.\n\nThe company is now conducting a surface electromagnetic (EM) survey at the Orient to target deeper anomalies generated by VTEM drilling
column506: as [reported](\n\nSpeaking to *Mining.com.au* on the sidelines of the [Noosa Mining Investor Conference]( Iltani Managing Director Donald Garner says the main revenue drivers for the project are silver
column509: and indium in that order.\n\n*“As long as gold sees high
column511: ”* Garner tells this news service.\n\nAs the festive season approaches
column512: silver has been enjoying its own holiday cheer
column513: marked at US$49.99 per ounce as of 24 November 2025
column514: indicating a 73.12% for the commodity’s value from this year to date [according]( to Trading Economics.\n\nZinc on the other hand is priced at US$3
column516: almost at a 1% increase for this year-to-date.\n\n*“Zinc recently almost touched a dollar fifty a pound
column517: which is really good to see. The Zinc TCs treatment charges are low
column519: ”* Garner adds.\n\n*“If we are successful with the permitting and development process
column520: we’ll be in production in three or four years’ time.”*\n\nAt the same conference
column521: Garner describes sentiment to be high ahead of the year’s end for miners across different commodities.\n\n*“There’s a resurgence in commodity prices
column523: but the base metals are doing well and you’ve got this increasing interest in critical minerals
column524: ”* Garner mentions.\n\n*“They want to see mining in the state. They want to see value created in the state
column526:
revenues – it’s a really good time to be working in Queensland.”*

Iltani is [receiving]( an $8 million investment from the Queensland Investment Corporation’s (QIC) Critical Minerals and Battery Technology Fund (QCMBTF) to further develop the Orient Project.

The total grant comprises $6 million in cash in exchange for a 2% royalty on future product sales from the greater Herberton Project if commercial production begins by the end of 2030
column528: as well as $2 million cash for the issue of 5.41 million shares.\n\nShares will be issued at $0.37 each
column529: indicating a 10% discount to the 20-day volume weighted average price prior to the agreement.\n\n*“Now with the funding from the QIC
column530: we’ll build on what we’ve got and do more
column531: ”* Garner adds.\n\nThe QIC is a state government-owned corporation that manages the QCMBTF to bolster businesses focused on supporting Queensland’s critical minerals supply chain
column532: holding $131.6 billion worth of assets under management as of 30 June 2025.\n\nGarner explains that while the Iltani’s main priority is exploring the Orient Project
column533: the company is always looking for opportunities to *“create value for shareholders”.*\n\n*“If we don’t look
column534: we won’t find and you’ll never know when we’ll come across one of those
column535:
”* Garner says.

*“We’re growing the team at Orient to make sure we deliver the best possible project for our shareholders and for Queensland.”*

The company will focus on drill targets inside the Caldera Complex including the Boonmoo gold and Union Jack base metal targets
column536: before mapping the Orient and Antimony Reward projects.\n\n*“Once we understand the controls of the mineralisation
column537: we might go back to Antimony Reward but our main focus is at Orient

column551: 2 Monster Stocks to Hold for the Next 5 Years - The Motley Fool
column553:
"* Multibagger stocks can grow your wealth exponentially.

* Niche players in high-potential industries can deliver monster returns over time.

* Robotics and rare earths are two such industries you'd want to look at right away.

These two stocks could skyrocket as they exploit their first-mover advantages in two massive industries.

Some stocks don't just outperform the broader markets -- they have the potential to deliver monumental returns over time
column554: supercharging your portfolio for years to come. They're not hard to find if you know where to look. Such stocks with [multibagger]( potential are often hidden among leaders in fast-growing industries
column555: first movers in industries with exponential potential
column556:
and innovative start-ups that are shaping the future.

Two such stocks have caught my attention. Each has such compelling growth prospects that buying them now and holding them could yield monster returns over the next five years or so.

Image source: Getty Images.

Rare-earth elements technically aren't rare
column557: but it's not easy to extract them in ways that are economically viable. China has a monopoly
column558: accounting for almost 70% of the global rare-earth extraction. That also means [80% of the rare-earth elements consumed in the U.S.]( are imported
column559: with nearly all of them coming from China.\n\nThat's not a great place to be. Rare-earth elements are vital for electronics
column566: China's dominance poses significant supply risks to the U.S. Additionally
column567: it has always disincentivized U.S. [mining]( companies from pouring money into rare-earth elements. President Donald Trump wants to change that and
column569: has allocated billions of dollars to critical mineral projects
column570: even buying stakes in some domestic producers to secure U.S. supply chains.\n\nThere is only one active rare-earth mine in the U.S.: the Mountain Pass in California
column571: owned and operated by **MP Materials** ([MP](/quote/nyse/mp/) +2.99%).\n\nIn July 2025
column573: rebranded as the Department of War (DOW) by Trump
column574: acquired a 15% stake in MP Materials and became its largest shareholder. MP Materials will build a rare-earth magnet manufacturing facility
column576:
with the DOW committing to purchase 100% of the rare-earth magnets produced at the facility for 10 years. Two of its other major deals include:

* A $500 million multiyear agreement with tech giant **Apple** ([AAPL](/quote/nasdaq/aapl/) +0.46%) to supply magnets.

* A partnership with the DOW and the Saudi Arabian Mining Company (Maaden) to develop a rare-earth refinery in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.

MP Materials currently produces rare-earth oxides and metals and will begin production of magnets by the end of 2025. [MP Materials stock already carries a market cap of $10 billion]( but that could look minuscule five years from now.

Shares of **Symbotic** ([SYM](/quote/nasdaq/sym/) 4.04%) have surged over 250% so far in 2025
column577: as of this writing. And there could be a lot more to come.\n\nSymbotic automates warehouses and distribution centers with [artificial intelligence (AI)]( [robotics]( that can move
column579: and sort items. Symbotic went public in 2022 but has been working with **Walmart** ([WMT](/quote/nyse/wmt/) +1.31%) since 2015 to deploy robotic systems at multiple distribution centers. In January 2025
column580: Symbotic acquired Walmart's advanced systems and robotics (ASR) business for automated fulfillment of orders
column581: a new product category for Symbotic.\n\nUnder yet another new and recent agreement
column582: Symbotic will develop and install automated micro-fulfillment systems for online pickup and delivery at Walmart's retail stores. Symbotic expects its first prototype to be ready in 2026. Meanwhile
column583: Symbotic is developing a next-generation storage technology as well. Besides Walmart
column587: and **Target**.\n\nSymbotic has also just announced something big: It has signed up Medline as a customer
column588: marking its foray into healthcare. [Medline is a major distributor of medical supplies]( in the U.S. and is expected to go public soon. Symbotic deployed its first system to Medline last quarter.\n\nSymbotic's entry into healthcare marks a significant milestone
column589: as it opens up a new vertical for the company beyond retail and could fast-track its sales growth. Symbotic just posted a 26% growth in revenue for the fiscal year that ended Sept. 27
column591: and projects similar growth for the first quarter of fiscal year 2026.\n\nMost importantly
column592: Symbotic ended the year with a backlog of $22.5 billion. That's huge
column593: as it represents nearly a decade's worth of sales. So
column594: even though Symbotic's market cap has surpassed $50 billion
column595: its estimated addressable market runs into the hundreds of billions of dollars
column596: making it a solid stock to own for the long term.\n\nBoth MP Materials and Symbotic share a common link -- they have the first-mover advantage in their respective industries
column597: *and* both industries have exponential growth potential. That's what makes these stocks so appealing. Growth stocks carry their share of risks
column598: but with both Symbotic and MP Materials already generating revenue and striking significant partnerships
column599: they're worth the risk.\n\nNeha Chamaria is a contributing Motley Fool stock market analyst covering energy
column603: with a focus on dividend stocks. Prior to The Motley Fool
column604: Neha worked on portfolio valuations for hedge funds at HSBC and authored articles as a journalist. She holds a master’s degree in finance from ICFAI and an MBA from Symbiosis University
column605: along with certifications from the National Stock Exchange of India. Neha was honored with an all-India gold medal for her M.S. in Finance and was the first woman in her family to pursue a professional career.\n\nInvest better with The Motley Fool. Get stock recommendations

column609: \"Australian miners thrust into spotlight as yttrium rockets 4
column612: \"There’s a village on the Swedish island of [Resarö]( in the Stockholm archipelago with residential streets named after chemical elements
column615: and Tantalum Road.\n\nThe streets may seem quiet and unassuming yet this village
column617: is one of the most important places in scientific history – it’s regarded as the single richest source of elemental discoveries in the world. [Yttrium]( (Y)
column620: and [ytterbium]( (Yb) are all named after the village.\n\nOther elements including holmium
column624: and thulium were first discovered there
column625: making Ytterby the richest source of naturally occurring elements on Earth.\n\nBack in 1787
column626: army lieutenant and part-time chemist Carl Axel Arrhenius discovered a strange
column627: unusually heavy black ore in an old quarry near Ytterby. This new ore was named by Arrhenius as ytterbite.\n\nTwo years later
column628: a Finnish chemist identified from Arrhenius’ initial sample the first rare earth element – named yttrium. In just over 50 years following Arrhenius’ original discovery
column629: Carl Gustav Mosander found that ytterbite was actually a mixture of three metal oxides
column630: and a fourth was later discovered by Jean Charles Galissard de Marignac from the original sample.\n\nEventually as refining techniques improved
column631: more new elements were discovered and ultimately over the next 100 years since Arrhenius’ discovery
column632: nine more elements fell out of this strange
column633: unusually heavy black ore.\n\nAmong these hard-to-pronounce elements is yttrium – a soft
column634: grey-white metal that is fairly stable in air but reacts with water
column636: and bases.\n\nIt occurs in other ‘rare earth’ minerals
column639: which is mined in China and Malaysia
column640: can contain up to 50% yttrium phosphate
column641: according to the Royal Society of Chemistry.\n\nYttrium metal is produced by reducing yttrium fluoride with calcium metal and is often used as an additive in alloys for its strengthening properties. When alloyed with aluminum
column644: it acts to strengthen those metals.\n\nIn addition to its applications in speciality alloys found in engines
column645: yttrium is used in coatings to shield against high temperatures.\n\nYttrium oxide is added to glass used to produce camera lenses as it makes them heat and shock resistant. It’s found in white LED lights as well as superconductors and lasers
column646: with yttrium oxysulfide widely sought to produce red phosphors for old-style colour television tubes.\n\nLasers that can cut through metals require yttrium-aluminium garnet (YAG)
column647: marking yet another of its many applications in everyday life.\n\nWhile its origins may come from Sweden
column648: like other rare earths and critical minerals
column649: China dominates global production and supply of yttrium. China supplies the US 93% of its yttrium imports
column650: creating acute vulnerability across Western supply chains.\n\nThe world’s supplies are now running low due to Chinese export restrictions
column651: sparking fears of looming protracted shortages
column652: and rocketing costs that could hit every sector from aerospace
column653: to energy and semiconductor production.\n\nOn the back of China restricting yttrium exports (along with six other rare earths in April in retaliation to the US tariffs) yttrium oxide (Y₂O₃) prices have been soaring more than 4
column656: as China’s tightening export controls disrupt global supply chains for military and defence
column659: and advanced materials. These shortages are also affecting markets related to high-temperature alloys
column662: and defence components.\n\nMagnet rare earth prices also remain high
column663: with Benchmark reporting Dy oxide (DDP China) at over US$200/kg and Tb oxide (DDP China) at almost US$1
column664:
000/kg.

[Victory Metals]( (ASX:VTM) CEO Brendan Clark says this global backdrop highlights the company’s strategic positioning as a major future yttrium supplier with what’s emerging as a valuable heavy rare earth basket.

The company’s current mineral resource hosts over 35 million kilograms of Y₂O₃ with forecast production targets over 600 tonnes annually tonnes along with strategic critical minerals dysprosium
column669:
and scandium.

Clark says yttrium is emerging as one of the world’s most important critical minerals and this global supply crunch is happening much faster than anyone expected.

*“Our North Stanmore deposit continues to demonstrate the scale
column671: and mineralogy required to supply Western nations with secure
column673: ”* the CEO adds.\n\nVictory is now advancing discussions with multiple strategic partners across the defence
column676: and semiconductor sectors seeking secure non-Chinese heavy rare earth supply.\n\nClark says the surge in yttrium pricing materially enhances Victory’s Prefeasibility Study (PFS)
column677: with the company continuing to integrate high value heavy rare earths including yttrium
column680: and recently confirmed gallium into its economic modelling.\n\nThe CEO recently told shareholders at the company’s AGM that China’s moves to ban the export of key defence-related minerals such as terbium
column681: dysprosium and scandium is an opportunity for Victory Metals to demonstrate its capability to produce these critical materials at scale and to help Australia become a key player in the global energy transition.\n\n*“We expect the PFS will define the processing pathway
column683: and production strategy for the North Stanmore project
column684: and demonstrate how the underlying resources can be turned into a commercial
column686: ”* Clark says.\n\nClark notes an exhaustive PFS into Victory’s flagship North Stanmore Project
column687: near Cue in Western Australia’s Mid West region
column688: continues to indicate the project’s potential as one of the most advanced heavy rare earth clay-hosted deposits.\n\n> ***“We are confident we can deliver significant grade increases in terbium
column689: dysprosium and scandium – three of the world’s most valuable and strategically critical elements”***\n\n*“Indications are we can avoid complex cracking or additional capital-intensive processing and environmental impacts
column690: which further strengthens our value as a secure
column691: reliable and capable potential supplier of high-purity feedstock to global processors
column692: ”* the CEO adds.\n\n*“With minimal processing under our proposed operating model
column693: we are confident we can deliver significant grade increases in terbium
column694: dysprosium and scandium – three of the world’s most valuable and strategically critical elements.”*\n\nOver the past 12 months
column695: Clark says Victory has attracted strong international and institutional backing
column696: and significant interest from government and private sector defence manufacturers around the world seeking secure off-take agreements.\n\nIn August 2025
column697: the company raised $11.5 million through a placement of new shares to institutional
column699: Victory signed a non-binding LoI with Japanese trading house Sumitomo Corporation to advance offtake and strategic cooperation for North Stanmore
column700: covering up to 30% of annual production
column701:
including up to 50 tonnes of Dy-Tb product over an initial five-year term.

The Export-Import Bank has also offered an LoI regarding funding support of US$190 million.

Victory Metals is among a number of Australian rare earths explorers thrust into the global spotlight
column702: following the landmark agreement between US President Donald Trump and Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese to facilitate the investment of the billions of dollars needed to establish secure and reliable rare earth and critical minerals supply chains.\n\nWith the state of the market
column703: [ABx Group]( (ASX:ABX) has also been ramping up efforts to become a significant player in rare earths space. It’s been raising $6.05 million through a placement to fund development activities at the Deep Leads Project in Tasmania and construction of the ALCORE pilot plant.\n\nFunds will be deployed to engineering and metallurgical studies
column704: exploration drilling for a resource increase
column705:
and to secure offtake agreements for the Deep Leads Project.

Proceeds will also cover construction and commissioning costs of the ALCORE pilot plant to produce hydrogen and fluoride from aluminium smelter bath waste.

The Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation ([ANSTO]( has started production of ABx’s first mixed rare earth carbonate (MREC) product using 50kg of a 100kg bulk sample
column706:
with completion expected before the end of November 2025.

The sample will be distributed to potential customers and offtake partners for evaluation.

ABx is running a program to produce a saleable MREC product from its Deep Leads ionic adsorption clay rare earth project in Tasmania to be used in downstream refining to produce separated rare earth oxides
column708: and magnets essential for EV motors
column711: and other clean-energy technologies.\n\nRare earth refineries (solvent-extraction plants) commonly accept MREC because it’s a standardised
column712: transportable feedstock from which high-purity rare earth oxides and metals can be produced.\n\nIn partnership with external engineering experts
column713: ABx conducted a formal processing options analysis. A key conclusion is that column leach tests should be conducted to confirm that the high extractions obtained in diagnostic leach tests in tanks are also observed in a column leach arrangement.\n\nANSTO is conducting initial column leach tests planned to begin in November
column714: with results available by early 2026.\n\nManaging Director of emerging rare earths producer [OD6 Metals]( (ASX:OD6)
column716: believes there is plenty of opportunity for Western countries like Australia to capture a substantial share of the burgeoning market dominated by China.\n\nRecently speaking to *Mining.com.au*
column717: Hazelden says US President Donald Trump is changing the way governments work with private industry
column718: which reshaping how government and private partnerships can work in an investor scheme to bolster Western supply chains.\n\nIf the Western world does not want all roads leading to China
column719: Hazelden argues they need to obviously pay a fair price that allows people to make money but also allows them to participate in the next part of the value chain as well.\n\nThe make-up of OD6’s Splinter Rock Rare Earth Elements Project in Western Australia opens up a plethora of potential end-user avenues for the minnow. The emerging rare earths producer has proven it can produce a clean
column721: which is a product highly sought after by several end users.\n\nOD6 has now identified another avenue for consideration down the track for the production of samarium and yttrium oxides
column722: which are both used in nuclear reactors for clean power generation and nuclear medicine.\n\nSamarium is also used in the manufacture of high-temperature samarium-cobalt magnets for headphones
column723: electric motors and aerospace applications.\n\nIn early October
column724: OD6 elected a preferred [flowsheet]( with the aim of producing MREC and mixed rare earth hydroxide (MREH). Flowsheet testing undertaken by ANSTO achieved a MREC recovery of about 56% total rare earth oxide (TREO)
column725: and a MREH recovery of roughly 59% TREO.\n\nThe process demonstrated low levels of aluminium
column728: and extremely low uranium and thorium content of less than 0.001%. Overall recoveries of the most in-demand magnet rare earths
column730: reached around 75% for OD6.\n\nThe high value magnet rare earths account for 23% of the TREO grade at Splinter Rock
column731: which hosts a resource so far of 682 million tonnes @ 1
column733: 000 tonnes of contained TREO. The magnet rare earths provide about 205
column734: 000 tonnes of the contained resource.\n\nMining.com.au Editor-in-Chief Adam Orlando has more than 20 years’ experience in the media having held senior roles at various publications
column735: including as Asia-Pacific Sector Head (Mining) at global newswire Acuris (formerly Mergermarket). Orlando has worked in newsrooms around the world including Hong Kong

and Sydney.

Here are all the silver stocks we are Invested in and ones to watch on Monday morning
