[BKB](/company/asx-jby/) - also now joined by explorer [PFE](/company/asx-pfe/).

You can read in more detail on the significance silver’s Friday surge and technical breakout in our Saturday note:

In this note we also wrote about why we think there will be a rally in small ASX stocks into the Christmas break.

Below is a summary and links for **everything else** we wrote about last week
column752: along with some other interesting content we found in relation to our Portfolio.\n\n**LKY** appointed [**Lockheed Martin strategy and risk manager**](/quick-takes/lky-adds-lockheed-martin-exec-to-its-advisory-board/)
column754:
to its advisory board.

*Stacy joins ex-Major General Peter Lambert as appointments to LKY’s team - both with existing networks into the US military industrial complex.*

*LKY is also advancing a white paper for “critical minerals into defence pathways” under the Defense Production Act. (aka government funding prep work)*

**LKY** also kicked off pre-drilling work on its US rare earths project
column755:
and will follow that up with drilling of its antimony project. LKY is anticipating a ‘[**continuous flow of exploration news and data through Q1 and Q2 of 2026**](

**WCE** hit silver in [**5 out of 8 zones**](/quick-takes/wce-hits-visible-silver-at-the-elizabeth-hill-mine-in-wa/) from its latest diamond drillholes.

*The results were from handheld XRF readings - so we will need to wait for final assays from these holes (due in mid-December).*

**BPM** released an update on [**its rare earth project**](/quick-takes/bpm-samples-rare-earth-oxide-grades-up-to-965-in-wa/) in WA.

*Rock chips grading up to 9.65% TREO
column756: within a newly confirmed 5km of mineralised strike... but most importantly
column757:
the same type of rocks that Iluka is looking to feed through its WA refinery that is under construction.*

The bigger news from **BPM** this week was that it [**raised $3.5M to help expand and accelerate drilling**](/quick-takes/bpm-raises-funds-drilling-on-wa-gold-asset-to-start-in-few-days/) at its WA gold project (*which should start in the coming weeks*).

**ILA** was [**added to the Medical Countermeasures Coalition**](/quick-takes/ila-added-to-a-coalition-of-companies-which-includes-multi-billion-dollar-big-pharma-companies/) (MC2) to advance US procurement and stockpiling opportunities.

*Some interesting names make up that coalition
column758:
including a few who have a proven track record developing drugs that went onto get big US stockpiling deals.*

**PNN** announced [**results from a drill program**](/quick-takes/pnn-now-weeks-away-from-10000m-drill-program-on-brazilian-rare-earths-asset/) on its Brazilian rare earth project.

*The results were from a shallow auger program
column759: and delivered further high grade niobium and rare earths results...*\n\n*Next PNN will kick off the first phase of a 10
column760:
000m RC drill program (due to start in December) ahead of a “maiden resource in Q1-2026”.*

**SGQ** hit [**extensions to its already large rare earths resource**](/quick-takes/sgq-hits-extensions-to-the-biggest-rare-earths-resources-deposit-in-south-america/) in Brazil.

*SGQ has 3 rigs drilling 24/7
column761:
29 assays in the lab and 40 more holes planned... so we should see more good news like this week’s results over the coming weeks/months.*

**KAU** is looking at ways [**to get more feed**](/quick-takes/kau-to-drill-waste-dumps-next-to-victorian-processing-plant/) through its processing plant in Victoria...

*One of those had samples with grades of 0.86g/t
column762:
the other 1.8g/t... both very processable grades especially so close to KAU’s Victorian plant and an all time high gold price.*

**ION** raised $4.4M to “*Advance E-Waste Recycling Opportunities in the USA*”.

*We participated in ION’s capital raise - we especially liked that there was almost no discount to the market price AND the board participated in the round (both good signals for a capital raise).*

**LSR** started its [**first exploration program**](/quick-takes/lsr-starts-exploration-on-us-heavy-rare-earths-project/) on its project in Arizona.

*Previous sampling at LSR’s project showed 0.53-1.26% TREO
column763:
importantly with ~57% heavy rare earths (the valuable ones).*

*The big win for us will be if LSR can show those same grades are consistent across a bigger part of its project.*

**SS1** [**released another drill result**](/quick-takes/ss1-hits-silver-and-gold-26m-above-its-existing-480m-ounce-silver-equivalent-resource/) from its 2025 drill program.

*The kicker for us was that mineralisation in the assay results started a lot closer to surface compared to where SS1’s resource estimate begins.*

*Near surface results could be a game changer for SS1’s project
column764:
removing all of the risks related to pre-stripping a deep orebody (i.e. mining the waste rock above the existing resource).*

**HAR** [**completed its second round of drilling**](/quick-takes/har-completes-drilling-on-gold-project-assay-results-coming-next-month/) on its gold project in Senegal.

*HAR is following up the results from a few months ago including the 20m intercept grading 6.54g/t gold.*

*HAR is moving very quickly here (which always makes us pay a lot more attention) and has already committed to deeper RC/diamond drilling in early 2026.*

This week **HAR** also [**confirmed a drill rig is on site**](/quick-takes/har-to-start-drilling-on-us-gold-project-today/) at its US based gold project in California **AND that drilling was scheduled to have started on the night shift of Friday 28th November.**

The goal is to convert the current resource to JORC compliant
column765:
and HAR expects to complete this by late January 2026.

**TTM** [**released more drill results**](/quick-takes/ttm-results-set-to-add-to-resource-as-lingbao-prepares-for-another-visit/) from its 3.1Moz gold and 22Moz silver project in Ecuador.

*More interesting to us though was the confirmation
column766: strategic investor Lingbao was “preparing a second site visit” as part of its due diligence toward doing a potential project level transaction with TTM for the Dynasty Gold Project.*\n\n**88E** put out an [**update on its projects in Alaska**](/quick-takes/88e-to-flow-test-well-next-to-711m-neighbour/)
column767: USA.\n\n*88E is fully carried for all costs associated with an upcoming horizontal well and extended flow test. 88E’s farm in partner is Burgundy Xploration
column768:
who is gearing up for an IPO in the US to support operational spend.*

**MNB** provided an [**update for its Cabinda phosphate project**](/quick-takes/mnb-update-on-angolan-phosphate-project/) in Angola.

*IF the alternative structure can be pulled off
column769: MNB could be fast-tracking first production by simplifying its processing flowsheet
column772: and dust extraction to cut ~$20M in CAPEX and $17/t operating costs.*\n\n*There is a fair bit to go through the announcement - Long story short
column773:
there looks to be a delay in the first production date mentioned months ago.*

**TG1** [**identified unmapped historical workings**](/quick-takes/tg1-finds-unmapped-historic-workings-on-recently-acquired-project/) at its Dalgaranga Gold Project in WA.

*TG1’s new project sits in a relatively well understood part of WA so it was a surprise to find unmapped historic workings. - a small open pit mined at 2.5g/t gold and multiple shallow workings.*

*Usually these historic workings are found on remote sites - so we liked that announcement from TG1.*

**L1M** [**raised $2.5M to fund drilling**](/quick-takes/l1m-raises-25m-exploration-programs-to-start-early-next-year/) on its QLD and NSW assets.

*We participated in the raise and we are looking forward to Phase 2 of L1M drilling its Queensland gold asset
column774:
following up the encouraging mineralisation it hit during Phase 1 drilling in recent months.*

**EIQ** has developed (and is already in the market with) an AI-powered algorithm that helps cardiologists detect heart diseases.

EIQ’s tech is already USA FDA approved AND being used by a growing number of hospitals in the USA to detect one heart disease called Aortic Stenosis.

**Earlier this week EIQ announced results of a clinical validation study on a different heart disease - Heart Failure.**

Heart Failure is one of the big heart diseases - US$60BN is spent on it
column776:
and it's the leading cause of rehospitalisation.

EIQ’s clinical validation study was run by the prestigious Mayo Clinic. The study delivered exceptional results on **detecting heart failure with 99.5% sensitivity and 91.0% specificity** ([source](

Much better than the only other AI heart failure detection software used in the market today which delivers **sensitivity of 87.8% and specificity of 81.9%** ([source](

(Both technologies are a step change from current practices where only 50% of Heart Failure cases are accurately diagnosed.)

IF EIQ can get FDA approval for its Heart Failure AI model
column777:
there already exists a reimbursement code the company can use to commercialise its AI tech.

The reimbursement code exists thanks to Ultromics (who [raised US$55M]( in a series C funding round valuing them at US$300M / A$464M back in July).

Now we watch for FDA clearance...

**IIQ** is developing an exosome platform technology.

IIQ is applying its exosome platform to develop diagnostics (detecting diseases) AND therapeutics (treating diseases).

Exosomes are tiny
column778:
microscopic extra-cellular “containers” that carry ‘messages’ between the human body's cells that allows the human body to function.

**IIQ is going after two types of cancer that have NO approved/recommended treatments or diagnostic tools.**

* Ovarian cancer is usually asymptomatic (no symptoms) in the early stages of the disease. If a woman is diagnosed at stage 1 - the survival rates can be over 90%. If a woman is diagnosed at stages 3/4 survival rates can be ~29%. ~70% of all ovarian cancer in Australia is diagnosed as advanced [stage 3 or 4 cancer](

* At the moment there are no recommended screening tests for women who show no symptoms of ovarian cancer - meaning there is no quick and easy screening test that can be regularly taken by all healthy women to catch ovarian cancer early.

* **IIQ’s screening test has been able to detect all stage 1 and 2 ovarian cancers (the earliest but asymptomatic stages where survival rates are the highest)
column779:
with over 99.6% specificity (catching 99.6% of all patients with cancer) AND NO misdiagnosis.**

* **What’s Next:** IIQ to do a larger clinical validation study (to see if the test works on a larger cohort of patients) then look at “strategic partnering” to commercialise the screening tool.

* Triple negative breast cancer is an aggressive type of breast cancer that does NOT respond to traditional breast cancer therapies.

* At the moment
column780:
there are no approved cell therapies treating triple negative breast cancer.

* IIQ is developing the therapeutic under a deal signed with the prestigious Peter MacCallum Cancer Centre (Peter Mac) in Melbourne. The institution is among only a handful globally that combines a dedicated cancer hospital with a fully integrated cancer research program.

* **So far IIQ has shown that its therapeutic was able to kill more than 90% of the cancer cells within 10 hours of treatment in in vitro studies (in a laboratory setting).**

* **What’s next:** Next for the therapeutic is the results from animal studies (in-vivo) due this quarter.

We think that any solid tumour therapeutic IIQ is able to develop could be a game changer for the company.

Mainly because it would de-risk IIQ’s platform tech (if it works for one cancer

column831: The Rare Earth Metal Driving Tensions Between the US and China - WIRED
column833: \"Yttrium plays a critical role in everything from aircraft engines to semiconductors. China controls the vast majority of the market—and that’s not changing anytime soon.\n\nThe alarm hasn't yet reached the general public
column834: but tension is beginning to build in the corridors of the aerospace industry
column836: and in government offices. For months
column837: an element almost invisible to the world—yttrium—has become the silent center of a new global dispute. Supplies are thinning
column839: deliveries are stalling. And while China and the United States have [promised a truce over rare earth minerals]( the wheels of advanced technology are beginning to slow.\n\nAlthough a late-October meeting in South Korea between Chinese president Xi Jinping and his US counterpart Donald Trump raised hopes for a détente
column840: the [Chinese export restrictions]( introduced last April remain substantially in place. Beijing granted a one-year reprieve on the mandatory government licensing system for shipments of rare earths and products containing related materials (including those made abroad with at least 0.1 percent Chinese resources)
column841: in exchange for a similar suspension of the White House's latest restrictions on technology supply chains.\n\nBut other measures introduced before the latest escalation remain in place. The result is a tightening of the international supply chain that threatens to slow advanced technological production
column843: and challenge entire industrial sectors. Yttrium plays a crucial role in the functioning of contemporary technologies. Without yttrium
column847: and semiconductors would immediately slow down.\n\nYttrium's value lies in its ability to impart thermal and mechanical strength to materials subjected to extreme temperatures. Jet engines blades
column849: must withstand prolonged overheating and intense vibration; yttrium is what allows them to maintain structural integrity and efficiency. The same is true for industrial chip manufacturing
column850: where yttrium-based coatings protect machinery from chemical wear and ensure precision in plasma etching. Its indispensable nature has made it a key element of modern technology and the military.\n\nThe problem is that
column852: China controls almost the entire global yttrium supply chain. Not only does it produce most of it
column853: but it also has the know-how and infrastructure to refine and separate it from other rare earth minerals
column854: a complex and technologically advanced process. According to US data
column855: the United States imports 100 percent of its yttrium needs
column856: 93 percent of which comes directly from China. Such stark dependence creates enormous geopolitical vulnerability.\n\nWhen Beijing decided to introduce export restrictions as a response to US tariffs
column857: the entire international supply structure began to falter. Companies reported delays
column859: and uncertainty about delivery times. In the rare earths trade
column860: lack of predictability is often more damaging than reduced volumes: An industry accustomed to just-in-time deliveries can be thrown into crisis by even a few weeks of delay.\n\nThe effects were immediate. In Europe
column863: 400 percent increase since the beginning of the year. Aerospace companies
column864: which rely heavily on this material
column865: have expressed alarm and demanded urgent measures from the US government to expand domestic production. The semiconductor industry is no less concerned: Some companies have called the situation a “serious” threat
column868: and production timelines. Gas-fired power plants
column869: which use yttrium in the protective coatings of turbines
column870: are also monitoring Chinese developments with increasing attention
column871: although they maintain that they have not yet experienced disruptions.\n\nThe situation in warehouses outside China adds further layers of complexity. Available reserves
column874: depending on the producers. Some traders have already reported running out of material; from quantities in the hundreds of tons range
column875: many are down to just a few units. Others are completely out of stock. This volatility makes the market extremely fragile and underscores how the global supply chain depends on a small number of players.\n\nChinese exports to several countries have fallen by about 30 percent. China
column876: which aims to become an autonomous tech powerhouse
column877: therefore maintains a position of strength and a high degree of discretion
column878: carefully regulating the quantities released to the international market. Moreover
column879: the measures introduced by Beijing in the sector from the outset are flexible enough to allow it to modulate the flow of shipments according to political priorities.\n\nOn the political front
column880: the trade truce between Washington and Beijing has yet to produce concrete results. The two sides have given negotiators until the end of November to outline clearer terms for rare earth exports to the United States
column881: but the gap between their respective priorities remains wide. Beijing continues to work on a licensing system
column882: inspired by mechanisms already used by the United States
column883: that would allow for faster flow only to companies deemed to have no ties to the US military industry. This would leave many Western companies operating in the delicate boundary between civilian production and defense applications at a disadvantage
column884: further complicating access to materials.\n\nChina's strategy involves not only controlling trade flows
column885: but also managing technical expertise internationally. Authorities have begun requiring detailed lists of technicians specializing in rare earths
column886: restricting their travel abroad and monitoring potential transfers of expertise to rival countries. At the same time
column887: bans on the export of advanced rare earth processing technologies continue
column888: a sector in which China holds a leadership position that is unlikely to be replicated in the short term. This dual approach—control of physical resources and human capital—strengthens Chinese primacy and hampers attempts to build an alternative supply chain.\n\nThe United States is nevertheless trying to fight back. New industrial projects
column889: such as that of ReElement Technologies in Indiana
column890: aim to produce yttrium oxide domestically starting in December
column891: with an initial capacity of 200 tons per year
column892: set to double within a few months. While this figure isn't enough to cover total US needs
column893: it represents a first step toward diversification.\n\nDuring Trump's recent visit to Asia
column894: Japan and the United States signed an agreement to jointly exploit the giant Minamitori undersea deposit
column895: discovered years ago in the Pacific seabed. Washington and Tokyo announced the launch of a joint study to develop technologies and infrastructure capable of extracting these strategic materials from extreme ocean depths
column896: a feat that will require enormous investment and advanced technical cooperation.\n\nYet the absence of a complete supply chain—from extraction to refining—makes the transition slow and complex. China has no intention of giving up its dominant position
column897:
a crucial and potentially decisive negotiating lever.

column1339: Meta Platforms may signal major AI market shift in 2026 - TheStreet
column1341:
"Meta’s quiet pivot gives Google new leverage and raises a question Nvidia investors can’t ignore.

* Nvidia's central role in AI faces subtle pressure as major tech players explore new chip strategies.

* Policy shifts and market dynamics are creating fresh momentum for domestic chipmakers in Asia.

* Even as the AI hardware space booms
column1342:
the competitive landscape is becoming more nuanced.

When you think of [AI]( the conversation invariably leads to [Nvidia]( The semiconductor giant is one of the biggest beneficiaries of the AI wave. It ended its [fiscal year with $130.5 billion in revenues]( which is more than double what it made in the previous year. Its data center division alone made $115.2 billion.

column1344: the market is posing a new question: what does “dominance” mean when your largest consumers are striving to need you less?\n\nOn one side

column1350:
from both ends of the global AI [supply chain](

* Beginning in 2027

column1352:
and almost $30 billion more than what it spent in 2024 at the midpoint.

Triple-digit growth meets Wall Street skepticism as Palantir battles AI bubble fears.

* Nvidia still dominates the AI accelerator market

column1354: some estimates suggest that a Meta–TPU transaction may cost Nvidia up to 10% of its annual sales.\n\nMarkets have noticed. Nvidia’s market value has [dropped by more than $700 billion]( since it briefly reached $5 trillion earlier this year. Alphabet’s stock has risen
column1355: bringing its market value closer to $4 trillion as [Wall Street]( begins to assign a real financial value to TPU sales.\n\nMorgan Stanley
column1358: 000 and 1 million TPUs]( per year by 2027. Every additional 500
column1359:
000 units would contribute around 11% to Google Cloud’s revenue and 3% to Alphabet’s profits per share.

That doesn’t eliminate Nvidia from the game overnight. But it does shift the debate from “Is it possible for anyone to catch Nvidia?” to “How much of the AI hardware market will Nvidia share with its competitors?”

If the conversations between Meta and Google are about diversifying

column1361:
which are available there.

Recently
column1362:
[Chinese officials stopped]( ByteDance from using Nvidia chips in new data centers and told state-funded projects to only utilize AI processors made in China. This means that they had to use a local alternative.

column1363:
planned for early 2027.

reaching about 8 billion yuan (about $1.1 billion) by 2026.

column1528: \"Australian miners thrust into spotlight as yttrium rockets 4
column1531: \"There’s a village on the Swedish island of [Resarö]( in the Stockholm archipelago with residential streets named after chemical elements
column1534: and Tantalum Road.\n\nThe streets may seem quiet and unassuming yet this village
column1536: is one of the most important places in scientific history – it’s regarded as the single richest source of elemental discoveries in the world. [Yttrium]( (Y)
column1539: and [ytterbium]( (Yb) are all named after the village.\n\nOther elements including holmium
column1543: and thulium were first discovered there
column1544: making Ytterby the richest source of naturally occurring elements on Earth.\n\nBack in 1787
column1545: army lieutenant and part-time chemist Carl Axel Arrhenius discovered a strange
column1546: unusually heavy black ore in an old quarry near Ytterby. This new ore was named by Arrhenius as ytterbite.\n\nTwo years later
column1547: a Finnish chemist identified from Arrhenius’ initial sample the first rare earth element – named yttrium. In just over 50 years following Arrhenius’ original discovery
column1548: Carl Gustav Mosander found that ytterbite was actually a mixture of three metal oxides
column1549: and a fourth was later discovered by Jean Charles Galissard de Marignac from the original sample.\n\nEventually as refining techniques improved
column1550: more new elements were discovered and ultimately over the next 100 years since Arrhenius’ discovery
column1551: nine more elements fell out of this strange
column1552: unusually heavy black ore.\n\nAmong these hard-to-pronounce elements is yttrium – a soft
column1553: grey-white metal that is fairly stable in air but reacts with water
column1555: and bases.\n\nIt occurs in other ‘rare earth’ minerals
column1558: which is mined in China and Malaysia
column1559: can contain up to 50% yttrium phosphate
column1560: according to the Royal Society of Chemistry.\n\nYttrium metal is produced by reducing yttrium fluoride with calcium metal and is often used as an additive in alloys for its strengthening properties. When alloyed with aluminum
column1563: it acts to strengthen those metals.\n\nIn addition to its applications in speciality alloys found in engines
column1564: yttrium is used in coatings to shield against high temperatures.\n\nYttrium oxide is added to glass used to produce camera lenses as it makes them heat and shock resistant. It’s found in white LED lights as well as superconductors and lasers
column1565: with yttrium oxysulfide widely sought to produce red phosphors for old-style colour television tubes.\n\nLasers that can cut through metals require yttrium-aluminium garnet (YAG)
column1566: marking yet another of its many applications in everyday life.\n\nWhile its origins may come from Sweden
column1567: like other rare earths and critical minerals
column1568: China dominates global production and supply of yttrium. China supplies the US 93% of its yttrium imports
column1569: creating acute vulnerability across Western supply chains.\n\nThe world’s supplies are now running low due to Chinese export restrictions
column1570: sparking fears of looming protracted shortages
column1571: and rocketing costs that could hit every sector from aerospace
column1572: to energy and semiconductor production.\n\nOn the back of China restricting yttrium exports (along with six other rare earths in April in retaliation to the US tariffs) yttrium oxide (Y₂O₃) prices have been soaring more than 4

000/kg.

column1659: Exploration funding reaches ‘turning point’ in Australia: report - Australian Mining
column1661: \"A new report suggests an “aggressive rush of capital” has hit Australia’s exploration sector as governments and investors move to strengthen and diversify critical mineral supply chains.\n\nThe *September quarterly cash update* report
column1662: released by professional services company BDO
column1663: shows $3.49 billion flowing into the sector as a result of investors and governments moving “more decisively” to [reinforce long-term critical minerals supply capabilities](\n\n“Australia’s traditional September fundraising slump did not materialise
column1664: with the quarter instead breaking a decade-long pattern of weakness
column1665:
” the report said.

The report marks the first time in four years that explorers have experienced consecutive quarterly [increases in funding]( – going against a “usual downturn” of cash inflow.

The quarter delivered an 81 per cent rise in funding from June
column1666: driven by 78 companies raising more than $10 million each and capturing $2.88 billion of the total inflow.\n\nThese positive numbers have been described as a turning point for exploration in Australia
column1667: with the race for strategic resources accelerating at a pace the market has not seen in years.\n\n“The scale of these raisings tells you exactly where global priorities are shifting
column1668: ” BDO global natural resources and energy leader Sherif Andrawes said.\n\n“Investors are backing assets that matter to energy security
column1669: electrification and industrial capability.”\n\nBoth copper and gold performed strongly in the quarter

column1676: The Rare Earth Metal Driving Tensions Between the US and China - WIRED
column1678: \"Yttrium plays a critical role in everything from aircraft engines to semiconductors. China controls the vast majority of the market—and that’s not changing anytime soon.\n\nThe alarm hasn't yet reached the general public
column1679: but tension is beginning to build in the corridors of the aerospace industry
column1681: and in government offices. For months
column1682: an element almost invisible to the world—yttrium—has become the silent center of a new global dispute. Supplies are thinning
column1684: deliveries are stalling. And while China and the United States have [promised a truce over rare earth minerals]( the wheels of advanced technology are beginning to slow.\n\nAlthough a late-October meeting in South Korea between Chinese president Xi Jinping and his US counterpart Donald Trump raised hopes for a détente
column1685: the [Chinese export restrictions]( introduced last April remain substantially in place. Beijing granted a one-year reprieve on the mandatory government licensing system for shipments of rare earths and products containing related materials (including those made abroad with at least 0.1 percent Chinese resources)
column1686: in exchange for a similar suspension of the White House's latest restrictions on technology supply chains.\n\nBut other measures introduced before the latest escalation remain in place. The result is a tightening of the international supply chain that threatens to slow advanced technological production
column1688: and challenge entire industrial sectors. Yttrium plays a crucial role in the functioning of contemporary technologies. Without yttrium
column1692: and semiconductors would immediately slow down.\n\nYttrium's value lies in its ability to impart thermal and mechanical strength to materials subjected to extreme temperatures. Jet engines blades
column1694: must withstand prolonged overheating and intense vibration; yttrium is what allows them to maintain structural integrity and efficiency. The same is true for industrial chip manufacturing
column1695: where yttrium-based coatings protect machinery from chemical wear and ensure precision in plasma etching. Its indispensable nature has made it a key element of modern technology and the military.\n\nThe problem is that
column1697: China controls almost the entire global yttrium supply chain. Not only does it produce most of it
column1698: but it also has the know-how and infrastructure to refine and separate it from other rare earth minerals
column1699: a complex and technologically advanced process. According to US data
column1700: the United States imports 100 percent of its yttrium needs
column1701: 93 percent of which comes directly from China. Such stark dependence creates enormous geopolitical vulnerability.\n\nWhen Beijing decided to introduce export restrictions as a response to US tariffs
column1702: the entire international supply structure began to falter. Companies reported delays
column1704: and uncertainty about delivery times. In the rare earths trade
column1705: lack of predictability is often more damaging than reduced volumes: An industry accustomed to just-in-time deliveries can be thrown into crisis by even a few weeks of delay.\n\nThe effects were immediate. In Europe
column1708: 400 percent increase since the beginning of the year. Aerospace companies
column1709: which rely heavily on this material
column1710: have expressed alarm and demanded urgent measures from the US government to expand domestic production. The semiconductor industry is no less concerned: Some companies have called the situation a “serious” threat
column1713: and production timelines. Gas-fired power plants
column1714: which use yttrium in the protective coatings of turbines
column1715: are also monitoring Chinese developments with increasing attention
column1716: although they maintain that they have not yet experienced disruptions.\n\nThe situation in warehouses outside China adds further layers of complexity. Available reserves
column1719: depending on the producers. Some traders have already reported running out of material; from quantities in the hundreds of tons range
column1720: many are down to just a few units. Others are completely out of stock. This volatility makes the market extremely fragile and underscores how the global supply chain depends on a small number of players.\n\nChinese exports to several countries have fallen by about 30 percent. China
column1721: which aims to become an autonomous tech powerhouse
column1722: therefore maintains a position of strength and a high degree of discretion
column1723: carefully regulating the quantities released to the international market. Moreover
column1724: the measures introduced by Beijing in the sector from the outset are flexible enough to allow it to modulate the flow of shipments according to political priorities.\n\nOn the political front
column1725: the trade truce between Washington and Beijing has yet to produce concrete results. The two sides have given negotiators until the end of November to outline clearer terms for rare earth exports to the United States
column1726: but the gap between their respective priorities remains wide. Beijing continues to work on a licensing system
column1727: inspired by mechanisms already used by the United States
column1728: that would allow for faster flow only to companies deemed to have no ties to the US military industry. This would leave many Western companies operating in the delicate boundary between civilian production and defense applications at a disadvantage
column1729: further complicating access to materials.\n\nChina's strategy involves not only controlling trade flows
column1730: but also managing technical expertise internationally. Authorities have begun requiring detailed lists of technicians specializing in rare earths
column1731: restricting their travel abroad and monitoring potential transfers of expertise to rival countries. At the same time
column1732: bans on the export of advanced rare earth processing technologies continue
column1733: a sector in which China holds a leadership position that is unlikely to be replicated in the short term. This dual approach—control of physical resources and human capital—strengthens Chinese primacy and hampers attempts to build an alternative supply chain.\n\nThe United States is nevertheless trying to fight back. New industrial projects
column1734: such as that of ReElement Technologies in Indiana
column1735: aim to produce yttrium oxide domestically starting in December
column1736: with an initial capacity of 200 tons per year
column1737: set to double within a few months. While this figure isn't enough to cover total US needs
column1738: it represents a first step toward diversification.\n\nDuring Trump's recent visit to Asia
column1739: Japan and the United States signed an agreement to jointly exploit the giant Minamitori undersea deposit
column1740: discovered years ago in the Pacific seabed. Washington and Tokyo announced the launch of a joint study to develop technologies and infrastructure capable of extracting these strategic materials from extreme ocean depths
column1741: a feat that will require enormous investment and advanced technical cooperation.\n\nYet the absence of a complete supply chain—from extraction to refining—makes the transition slow and complex. China has no intention of giving up its dominant position
column1742:
a crucial and potentially decisive negotiating lever.

column1896: 2 Monster Stocks to Hold for the Next 5 Years - The Motley Fool
column1898:
"* Multibagger stocks can grow your wealth exponentially.

* Niche players in high-potential industries can deliver monster returns over time.

* Robotics and rare earths are two such industries you'd want to look at right away.

These two stocks could skyrocket as they exploit their first-mover advantages in two massive industries.

Some stocks don't just outperform the broader markets -- they have the potential to deliver monumental returns over time
column1899: supercharging your portfolio for years to come. They're not hard to find if you know where to look. Such stocks with [multibagger]( potential are often hidden among leaders in fast-growing industries
column1900: first movers in industries with exponential potential
column1901:
and innovative start-ups that are shaping the future.

Two such stocks have caught my attention. Each has such compelling growth prospects that buying them now and holding them could yield monster returns over the next five years or so.

Image source: Getty Images.

Rare-earth elements technically aren't rare
column1902: but it's not easy to extract them in ways that are economically viable. China has a monopoly
column1903: accounting for almost 70% of the global rare-earth extraction. That also means [80% of the rare-earth elements consumed in the U.S.]( are imported
column1904: with nearly all of them coming from China.\n\nThat's not a great place to be. Rare-earth elements are vital for electronics
column1911: China's dominance poses significant supply risks to the U.S. Additionally
column1912: it has always disincentivized U.S. [mining]( companies from pouring money into rare-earth elements. President Donald Trump wants to change that and
column1914: has allocated billions of dollars to critical mineral projects
column1915: even buying stakes in some domestic producers to secure U.S. supply chains.\n\nThere is only one active rare-earth mine in the U.S.: the Mountain Pass in California
column1916: owned and operated by **MP Materials** ([MP](/quote/nyse/mp/) +2.99%).\n\nIn July 2025
column1918: rebranded as the Department of War (DOW) by Trump
column1919: acquired a 15% stake in MP Materials and became its largest shareholder. MP Materials will build a rare-earth magnet manufacturing facility
column1921:
with the DOW committing to purchase 100% of the rare-earth magnets produced at the facility for 10 years. Two of its other major deals include:

* A $500 million multiyear agreement with tech giant **Apple** ([AAPL](/quote/nasdaq/aapl/) +0.46%) to supply magnets.

* A partnership with the DOW and the Saudi Arabian Mining Company (Maaden) to develop a rare-earth refinery in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.

MP Materials currently produces rare-earth oxides and metals and will begin production of magnets by the end of 2025. [MP Materials stock already carries a market cap of $10 billion]( but that could look minuscule five years from now.

Shares of **Symbotic** ([SYM](/quote/nasdaq/sym/) 4.04%) have surged over 250% so far in 2025
column1922: as of this writing. And there could be a lot more to come.\n\nSymbotic automates warehouses and distribution centers with [artificial intelligence (AI)]( [robotics]( that can move
column1924: and sort items. Symbotic went public in 2022 but has been working with **Walmart** ([WMT](/quote/nyse/wmt/) +1.31%) since 2015 to deploy robotic systems at multiple distribution centers. In January 2025
column1925: Symbotic acquired Walmart's advanced systems and robotics (ASR) business for automated fulfillment of orders
column1926: a new product category for Symbotic.\n\nUnder yet another new and recent agreement
column1927: Symbotic will develop and install automated micro-fulfillment systems for online pickup and delivery at Walmart's retail stores. Symbotic expects its first prototype to be ready in 2026. Meanwhile
column1928: Symbotic is developing a next-generation storage technology as well. Besides Walmart
column1932: and **Target**.\n\nSymbotic has also just announced something big: It has signed up Medline as a customer
column1933: marking its foray into healthcare. [Medline is a major distributor of medical supplies]( in the U.S. and is expected to go public soon. Symbotic deployed its first system to Medline last quarter.\n\nSymbotic's entry into healthcare marks a significant milestone
column1934: as it opens up a new vertical for the company beyond retail and could fast-track its sales growth. Symbotic just posted a 26% growth in revenue for the fiscal year that ended Sept. 27
column1936: and projects similar growth for the first quarter of fiscal year 2026.\n\nMost importantly
column1937: Symbotic ended the year with a backlog of $22.5 billion. That's huge
column1938: as it represents nearly a decade's worth of sales. So
column1939: even though Symbotic's market cap has surpassed $50 billion
column1940: its estimated addressable market runs into the hundreds of billions of dollars
column1941: making it a solid stock to own for the long term.\n\nBoth MP Materials and Symbotic share a common link -- they have the first-mover advantage in their respective industries
column1942: *and* both industries have exponential growth potential. That's what makes these stocks so appealing. Growth stocks carry their share of risks
column1943: but with both Symbotic and MP Materials already generating revenue and striking significant partnerships
column1944: they're worth the risk.\n\nNeha Chamaria is a contributing Motley Fool stock market analyst covering energy
column1948: with a focus on dividend stocks. Prior to The Motley Fool
column1949: Neha worked on portfolio valuations for hedge funds at HSBC and authored articles as a journalist. She holds a master’s degree in finance from ICFAI and an MBA from Symbiosis University
column1950: along with certifications from the National Stock Exchange of India. Neha was honored with an all-India gold medal for her M.S. in Finance and was the first woman in her family to pursue a professional career.\n\nInvest better with The Motley Fool. Get stock recommendations
column1952: and more from The Motley Fool's premium services.\"

(hitting the highest price in its history and delivering a key breakout of a 50 year chart pattern we have been watching...)

[BKB](/company/asx-jby/) - also now joined by explorer [PFE](/company/asx-pfe/).

In this note we also wrote about why we think there will be a rally in small ASX stocks into the Christmas break.

Below is a summary and links for **everything else** we wrote about last week
column1966: along with some other interesting content we found in relation to our Portfolio.\n\n**LKY** appointed [**Lockheed Martin strategy and risk manager**](/quick-takes/lky-adds-lockheed-martin-exec-to-its-advisory-board/)
column1968:
to its advisory board.

*Stacy joins ex-Major General Peter Lambert as appointments to LKY’s team - both with existing networks into the US military industrial complex.*

*LKY is also advancing a white paper for “critical minerals into defence pathways” under the Defense Production Act. (aka government funding prep work)*

**LKY** also kicked off pre-drilling work on its US rare earths project
column1969:
and will follow that up with drilling of its antimony project. LKY is anticipating a ‘[**continuous flow of exploration news and data through Q1 and Q2 of 2026**](

**WCE** hit silver in [**5 out of 8 zones**](/quick-takes/wce-hits-visible-silver-at-the-elizabeth-hill-mine-in-wa/) from its latest diamond drillholes.

*The results were from handheld XRF readings - so we will need to wait for final assays from these holes (due in mid-December).*

**BPM** released an update on [**its rare earth project**](/quick-takes/bpm-samples-rare-earth-oxide-grades-up-to-965-in-wa/) in WA.

*Rock chips grading up to 9.65% TREO
column1970: within a newly confirmed 5km of mineralised strike... but most importantly
column1971:
the same type of rocks that Iluka is looking to feed through its WA refinery that is under construction.*

The bigger news from **BPM** this week was that it [**raised $3.5M to help expand and accelerate drilling**](/quick-takes/bpm-raises-funds-drilling-on-wa-gold-asset-to-start-in-few-days/) at its WA gold project (*which should start in the coming weeks*).

**ILA** was [**added to the Medical Countermeasures Coalition**](/quick-takes/ila-added-to-a-coalition-of-companies-which-includes-multi-billion-dollar-big-pharma-companies/) (MC2) to advance US procurement and stockpiling opportunities.

*Some interesting names make up that coalition
column1972:
including a few who have a proven track record developing drugs that went onto get big US stockpiling deals.*

**PNN** announced [**results from a drill program**](/quick-takes/pnn-now-weeks-away-from-10000m-drill-program-on-brazilian-rare-earths-asset/) on its Brazilian rare earth project.

*The results were from a shallow auger program
column1973: and delivered further high grade niobium and rare earths results...*\n\n*Next PNN will kick off the first phase of a 10
column1974:
000m RC drill program (due to start in December) ahead of a “maiden resource in Q1-2026”.*

**SGQ** hit [**extensions to its already large rare earths resource**](/quick-takes/sgq-hits-extensions-to-the-biggest-rare-earths-resources-deposit-in-south-america/) in Brazil.

*SGQ has 3 rigs drilling 24/7
column1975:
29 assays in the lab and 40 more holes planned... so we should see more good news like this week’s results over the coming weeks/months.*

**KAU** is looking at ways [**to get more feed**](/quick-takes/kau-to-drill-waste-dumps-next-to-victorian-processing-plant/) through its processing plant in Victoria...

*One of those had samples with grades of 0.86g/t
column1976:
the other 1.8g/t... both very processable grades especially so close to KAU’s Victorian plant and an all time high gold price.*

**ION** raised $4.4M to “*Advance E-Waste Recycling Opportunities in the USA*”.

*We participated in ION’s capital raise - we especially liked that there was almost no discount to the market price AND the board participated in the round (both good signals for a capital raise).*

**LSR** started its [**first exploration program**](/quick-takes/lsr-starts-exploration-on-us-heavy-rare-earths-project/) on its project in Arizona.

*Previous sampling at LSR’s project showed 0.53-1.26% TREO
column1977:
importantly with ~57% heavy rare earths (the valuable ones).*

*The big win for us will be if LSR can show those same grades are consistent across a bigger part of its project.*

**SS1** [**released another drill result**](/quick-takes/ss1-hits-silver-and-gold-26m-above-its-existing-480m-ounce-silver-equivalent-resource/) from its 2025 drill program.

*The kicker for us was that mineralisation in the assay results started a lot closer to surface compared to where SS1’s resource estimate begins.*

*Near surface results could be a game changer for SS1’s project

**EIQ** has developed (and is already in the market with) an AI-powered algorithm that helps cardiologists detect heart diseases.

EIQ’s tech is already USA FDA approved AND being used by a growing number of hospitals in the USA to detect one heart disease called Aortic Stenosis.

**Earlier this week EIQ announced results of a clinical validation study on a different heart disease - Heart Failure.**

Heart Failure is one of the big heart diseases - US$60BN is spent on it
column1990:
and it's the leading cause of rehospitalisation.

EIQ’s clinical validation study was run by the prestigious Mayo Clinic. The study delivered exceptional results on **detecting heart failure with 99.5% sensitivity and 91.0% specificity** ([source](

Much better than the only other AI heart failure detection software used in the market today which delivers **sensitivity of 87.8% and specificity of 81.9%** ([source](

(Both technologies are a step change from current practices where only 50% of Heart Failure cases are accurately diagnosed.)

IF EIQ can get FDA approval for its Heart Failure AI model
column1991:
there already exists a reimbursement code the company can use to commercialise its AI tech.

The reimbursement code exists thanks to Ultromics (who [raised US$55M]( in a series C funding round valuing them at US$300M / A$464M back in July).

Now we watch for FDA clearance...

**IIQ** is developing an exosome platform technology.

IIQ is applying its exosome platform to develop diagnostics (detecting diseases) AND therapeutics (treating diseases).

Exosomes are tiny
column1992:
microscopic extra-cellular “containers” that carry ‘messages’ between the human body's cells that allows the human body to function.

**IIQ is going after two types of cancer that have NO approved/recommended treatments or diagnostic tools.**

* Ovarian cancer is usually asymptomatic (no symptoms) in the early stages of the disease. If a woman is diagnosed at stage 1 - the survival rates can be over 90%. If a woman is diagnosed at stages 3/4 survival rates can be ~29%. ~70% of all ovarian cancer in Australia is diagnosed as advanced [stage 3 or 4 cancer](

* At the moment there are no recommended screening tests for women who show no symptoms of ovarian cancer - meaning there is no quick and easy screening test that can be regularly taken by all healthy women to catch ovarian cancer early.

* **IIQ’s screening test has been able to detect all stage 1 and 2 ovarian cancers (the earliest but asymptomatic stages where survival rates are the highest)
column1993:
with over 99.6% specificity (catching 99.6% of all patients with cancer) AND NO misdiagnosis.**

* **What’s Next:** IIQ to do a larger clinical validation study (to see if the test works on a larger cohort of patients) then look at “strategic partnering” to commercialise the screening tool.

* Triple negative breast cancer is an aggressive type of breast cancer that does NOT respond to traditional breast cancer therapies.

* At the moment
column1994:
there are no approved cell therapies treating triple negative breast cancer.

* IIQ is developing the therapeutic under a deal signed with the prestigious Peter MacCallum Cancer Centre (Peter Mac) in Melbourne. The institution is among only a handful globally that combines a dedicated cancer hospital with a fully integrated cancer research program.

* **So far IIQ has shown that its therapeutic was able to kill more than 90% of the cancer cells within 10 hours of treatment in in vitro studies (in a laboratory setting).**

* **What’s next:** Next for the therapeutic is the results from animal studies (in-vivo) due this quarter.

We think that any solid tumour therapeutic IIQ is able to develop could be a game changer for the company.

Mainly because it would de-risk IIQ’s platform tech (if it works for one cancer

column2103: The Rare Earth Metal Driving Tensions Between the US and China - WIRED
column2105: \"Yttrium plays a critical role in everything from aircraft engines to semiconductors. China controls the vast majority of the market—and that’s not changing anytime soon.\n\nThe alarm hasn't yet reached the general public
column2106: but tension is beginning to build in the corridors of the aerospace industry
column2108: and in government offices. For months
column2109: an element almost invisible to the world—yttrium—has become the silent center of a new global dispute. Supplies are thinning
column2111: deliveries are stalling. And while China and the United States have [promised a truce over rare earth minerals]( the wheels of advanced technology are beginning to slow.\n\nAlthough a late-October meeting in South Korea between Chinese president Xi Jinping and his US counterpart Donald Trump raised hopes for a détente
column2112: the [Chinese export restrictions]( introduced last April remain substantially in place. Beijing granted a one-year reprieve on the mandatory government licensing system for shipments of rare earths and products containing related materials (including those made abroad with at least 0.1 percent Chinese resources)
column2113: in exchange for a similar suspension of the White House's latest restrictions on technology supply chains.\n\nBut other measures introduced before the latest escalation remain in place. The result is a tightening of the international supply chain that threatens to slow advanced technological production
column2115: and challenge entire industrial sectors. Yttrium plays a crucial role in the functioning of contemporary technologies. Without yttrium
column2119: and semiconductors would immediately slow down.\n\nYttrium's value lies in its ability to impart thermal and mechanical strength to materials subjected to extreme temperatures. Jet engines blades
column2121: must withstand prolonged overheating and intense vibration; yttrium is what allows them to maintain structural integrity and efficiency. The same is true for industrial chip manufacturing
column2122: where yttrium-based coatings protect machinery from chemical wear and ensure precision in plasma etching. Its indispensable nature has made it a key element of modern technology and the military.\n\nThe problem is that
column2124: China controls almost the entire global yttrium supply chain. Not only does it produce most of it
column2125: but it also has the know-how and infrastructure to refine and separate it from other rare earth minerals
column2126: a complex and technologically advanced process. According to US data
column2127: the United States imports 100 percent of its yttrium needs
column2128: 93 percent of which comes directly from China. Such stark dependence creates enormous geopolitical vulnerability.\n\nWhen Beijing decided to introduce export restrictions as a response to US tariffs
column2129: the entire international supply structure began to falter. Companies reported delays
column2131: and uncertainty about delivery times. In the rare earths trade
column2132: lack of predictability is often more damaging than reduced volumes: An industry accustomed to just-in-time deliveries can be thrown into crisis by even a few weeks of delay.\n\nThe effects were immediate. In Europe
column2135: 400 percent increase since the beginning of the year. Aerospace companies
column2136: which rely heavily on this material
column2137: have expressed alarm and demanded urgent measures from the US government to expand domestic production. The semiconductor industry is no less concerned: Some companies have called the situation a “serious” threat
column2140: and production timelines. Gas-fired power plants
column2141: which use yttrium in the protective coatings of turbines
column2142: are also monitoring Chinese developments with increasing attention
column2143: although they maintain that they have not yet experienced disruptions.\n\nThe situation in warehouses outside China adds further layers of complexity. Available reserves
column2146: depending on the producers. Some traders have already reported running out of material; from quantities in the hundreds of tons range
column2147: many are down to just a few units. Others are completely out of stock. This volatility makes the market extremely fragile and underscores how the global supply chain depends on a small number of players.\n\nChinese exports to several countries have fallen by about 30 percent. China
column2148: which aims to become an autonomous tech powerhouse
column2149: therefore maintains a position of strength and a high degree of discretion
column2150: carefully regulating the quantities released to the international market. Moreover
column2151: the measures introduced by Beijing in the sector from the outset are flexible enough to allow it to modulate the flow of shipments according to political priorities.\n\nOn the political front
column2152: the trade truce between Washington and Beijing has yet to produce concrete results. The two sides have given negotiators until the end of November to outline clearer terms for rare earth exports to the United States
column2153: but the gap between their respective priorities remains wide. Beijing continues to work on a licensing system
column2154: inspired by mechanisms already used by the United States
column2155: that would allow for faster flow only to companies deemed to have no ties to the US military industry. This would leave many Western companies operating in the delicate boundary between civilian production and defense applications at a disadvantage
column2156: further complicating access to materials.\n\nChina's strategy involves not only controlling trade flows
column2157: but also managing technical expertise internationally. Authorities have begun requiring detailed lists of technicians specializing in rare earths
column2158: restricting their travel abroad and monitoring potential transfers of expertise to rival countries. At the same time
column2159: bans on the export of advanced rare earth processing technologies continue
column2160: a sector in which China holds a leadership position that is unlikely to be replicated in the short term. This dual approach—control of physical resources and human capital—strengthens Chinese primacy and hampers attempts to build an alternative supply chain.\n\nThe United States is nevertheless trying to fight back. New industrial projects
column2161: such as that of ReElement Technologies in Indiana
column2162: aim to produce yttrium oxide domestically starting in December
column2163: with an initial capacity of 200 tons per year
column2164: set to double within a few months. While this figure isn't enough to cover total US needs
column2165: it represents a first step toward diversification.\n\nDuring Trump's recent visit to Asia
column2166: Japan and the United States signed an agreement to jointly exploit the giant Minamitori undersea deposit
column2167: discovered years ago in the Pacific seabed. Washington and Tokyo announced the launch of a joint study to develop technologies and infrastructure capable of extracting these strategic materials from extreme ocean depths
column2168: a feat that will require enormous investment and advanced technical cooperation.\n\nYet the absence of a complete supply chain—from extraction to refining—makes the transition slow and complex. China has no intention of giving up its dominant position
column2169:
a crucial and potentially decisive negotiating lever.

column2181: \"Australian miners thrust into spotlight as yttrium rockets 4
column2184: \"There’s a village on the Swedish island of [Resarö]( in the Stockholm archipelago with residential streets named after chemical elements
column2187: and Tantalum Road.\n\nThe streets may seem quiet and unassuming yet this village
column2189: is one of the most important places in scientific history – it’s regarded as the single richest source of elemental discoveries in the world. [Yttrium]( (Y)
column2192: and [ytterbium]( (Yb) are all named after the village.\n\nOther elements including holmium
column2196: and thulium were first discovered there
column2197: making Ytterby the richest source of naturally occurring elements on Earth.\n\nBack in 1787
column2198: army lieutenant and part-time chemist Carl Axel Arrhenius discovered a strange
column2199: unusually heavy black ore in an old quarry near Ytterby. This new ore was named by Arrhenius as ytterbite.\n\nTwo years later
column2200: a Finnish chemist identified from Arrhenius’ initial sample the first rare earth element – named yttrium. In just over 50 years following Arrhenius’ original discovery
column2201: Carl Gustav Mosander found that ytterbite was actually a mixture of three metal oxides
column2202: and a fourth was later discovered by Jean Charles Galissard de Marignac from the original sample.\n\nEventually as refining techniques improved
column2203: more new elements were discovered and ultimately over the next 100 years since Arrhenius’ discovery
column2204: nine more elements fell out of this strange
column2205: unusually heavy black ore.\n\nAmong these hard-to-pronounce elements is yttrium – a soft
column2206: grey-white metal that is fairly stable in air but reacts with water
column2208: and bases.\n\nIt occurs in other ‘rare earth’ minerals
column2211: which is mined in China and Malaysia
column2212: can contain up to 50% yttrium phosphate
column2213: according to the Royal Society of Chemistry.\n\nYttrium metal is produced by reducing yttrium fluoride with calcium metal and is often used as an additive in alloys for its strengthening properties. When alloyed with aluminum
column2216: it acts to strengthen those metals.\n\nIn addition to its applications in speciality alloys found in engines
column2217: yttrium is used in coatings to shield against high temperatures.\n\nYttrium oxide is added to glass used to produce camera lenses as it makes them heat and shock resistant. It’s found in white LED lights as well as superconductors and lasers
column2218: with yttrium oxysulfide widely sought to produce red phosphors for old-style colour television tubes.\n\nLasers that can cut through metals require yttrium-aluminium garnet (YAG)
column2219: marking yet another of its many applications in everyday life.\n\nWhile its origins may come from Sweden

column2314: \"# Foreign media on Kazakhstan: Kazakhstan enters global rare earth metals arena; How Kazakhstan’s female entrepreneurs leading Central Asia’s tech revolution\n\nBased on recent developments
column2315: including Kazakhstan’s deepening cooperation with Turkmenistan as the presidents of both countries conclude high level talks in Astana

column2318: [Qazinform News Agency]( presents a weekly review of foreign media coverage.\n\nAfter wrapping up high-level talks in Astana
column2319: Presidents Kassym-Jomart Tokayev of Kazakhstan and Serdar Berdimuhamedov of Turkmenistan came together to sign a Joint Statement focused on boosting their bilateral relations
column2320:
[Trend.az]( reports.

Among the key agreements was a Joint Action Plan for Transport Cooperation between the two countries for 2026-2027.

Moreover
column2321: the officials from both countries shook hands and put pen to paper on agreements that span a broad spectrum of sectors
column2325:
the sides agreed on enhanced pension system cooperation and signed a memorandum to advance veterinary services and agricultural research.

Kazakhstan’s National Academy of Sciences and Turkmenistan’s Academy of Sciences also agreed to increase research collaboration.

According to [The Times of Central Asia]( Kazakhstan
column2326: long recognized for its substantial rare earth metals reserves
column2327: is moving beyond the familiar characterization of “underutilized potential” and is taking on a more active role in global critical material supply chains. The state-owned mining company Tau-Ken Samruk has become a key driver of this shift
column2328: expanding both at home and abroad.\n\nKazakhstan recently confirmed a new deposit with major reserves of cerium
column2332: strengthening its position as one of the few countries producing more than half of the known rare earth elements. The national strategy now centers on developing a full industrial cycle rather than exporting raw materials.\n\nA clear example of this change came in 2025
column2333: when Tau-Ken Samruk signed an agreement with U.S. based Cove Capital to develop the Severny Katpar and Verkhniy Kairakty tungsten deposits. A similar project with China’s Xiamen Tungsten collapsed in 2018 without binding commitments
column2334: highlighting growing geopolitical competition around Kazakhstan’s resources.\n\nThe country is also expanding internationally. According to Samruk-Kazyna chairman Nurlan Zhakupov

column2337: noting exploration projects underway in Rwanda and Afghanistan.\n\nThese efforts illustrate Kazakhstan’s ambition to secure a larger role in global supply chains. Despite political and security risks abroad

column2339: entering the sector from diverse backgrounds and driving new forms of innovation
column2340: [Euronews]( reports.\n\nA key figure in this movement is Assem Bolatzhan

column2342: ” she says.\n\nAccording to Women in Tech Astana lead Rinata Ilyubayeva

column2345: and solutions for children with autism
column2348:
” she notes.

The momentum has led to the creation of Central Asia’s first female-focused venture capital initiative.

“We are building a platform to support women
column2350:
” says Ilyubayeva.

Entrepreneurs like Aigerim Nurgaliyeva show how women without technical training can succeed.

“The first obstacle was in my mind

**EIQ** has developed (and is already in the market with) an AI-powered algorithm that helps cardiologists detect heart diseases.

EIQ’s tech is already USA FDA approved AND being used by a growing number of hospitals in the USA to detect one heart disease called Aortic Stenosis.

**Earlier this week EIQ announced results of a clinical validation study on a different heart disease - Heart Failure.**

Heart Failure is one of the big heart diseases - US$60BN is spent on it
column2420:
and it's the leading cause of rehospitalisation.

EIQ’s clinical validation study was run by the prestigious Mayo Clinic. The study delivered exceptional results on **detecting heart failure with 99.5% sensitivity and 91.0% specificity** ([source](

Much better than the only other AI heart failure detection software used in the market today which delivers **sensitivity of 87.8% and specificity of 81.9%** ([source](

(Both technologies are a step change from current practices where only 50% of Heart Failure cases are accurately diagnosed.)

IF EIQ can get FDA approval for its Heart Failure AI model
column2421:
there already exists a reimbursement code the company can use to commercialise its AI tech.

The reimbursement code exists thanks to Ultromics (who [raised US$55M]( in a series C funding round valuing them at US$300M / A$464M back in July).

Now we watch for FDA clearance...

**IIQ** is developing an exosome platform technology.

IIQ is applying its exosome platform to develop diagnostics (detecting diseases) AND therapeutics (treating diseases).

Exosomes are tiny
column2422:
microscopic extra-cellular “containers” that carry ‘messages’ between the human body's cells that allows the human body to function.

**IIQ is going after two types of cancer that have NO approved/recommended treatments or diagnostic tools.**

* Ovarian cancer is usually asymptomatic (no symptoms) in the early stages of the disease. If a woman is diagnosed at stage 1 - the survival rates can be over 90%. If a woman is diagnosed at stages 3/4 survival rates can be ~29%. ~70% of all ovarian cancer in Australia is diagnosed as advanced [stage 3 or 4 cancer](

* At the moment there are no recommended screening tests for women who show no symptoms of ovarian cancer - meaning there is no quick and easy screening test that can be regularly taken by all healthy women to catch ovarian cancer early.

* **IIQ’s screening test has been able to detect all stage 1 and 2 ovarian cancers (the earliest but asymptomatic stages where survival rates are the highest)
column2423:
with over 99.6% specificity (catching 99.6% of all patients with cancer) AND NO misdiagnosis.**

* **What’s Next:** IIQ to do a larger clinical validation study (to see if the test works on a larger cohort of patients) then look at “strategic partnering” to commercialise the screening tool.

* Triple negative breast cancer is an aggressive type of breast cancer that does NOT respond to traditional breast cancer therapies.

* At the moment
column2424:
there are no approved cell therapies treating triple negative breast cancer.

* IIQ is developing the therapeutic under a deal signed with the prestigious Peter MacCallum Cancer Centre (Peter Mac) in Melbourne. The institution is among only a handful globally that combines a dedicated cancer hospital with a fully integrated cancer research program.

* **So far IIQ has shown that its therapeutic was able to kill more than 90% of the cancer cells within 10 hours of treatment in in vitro studies (in a laboratory setting).**

* **What’s next:** Next for the therapeutic is the results from animal studies (in-vivo) due this quarter.

We think that any solid tumour therapeutic IIQ is able to develop could be a game changer for the company.

Mainly because it would de-risk IIQ’s platform tech (if it works for one cancer

**EXR** is the biggest net acreage holder in the Taroom Trough - second only to supermajor $320BN Shell.

EXR just did a deal with the #3 landholder in the region - Omega Oil and Gas.

Omega took a 19.43% position in EXR in exchange for $13.9M at 4.1c per share.

Omega is backed by Tri-Star (pioneers of the Queensland gas industry) and it recently did a deal with ~$2.8BN Beach Energy.

After all is said and done EXR will have a $35.3M capital budget to work with.

column2573: \"Australian miners thrust into spotlight as yttrium rockets 4
column2576: \"There’s a village on the Swedish island of [Resarö]( in the Stockholm archipelago with residential streets named after chemical elements
column2579: and Tantalum Road.\n\nThe streets may seem quiet and unassuming yet this village
column2581: is one of the most important places in scientific history – it’s regarded as the single richest source of elemental discoveries in the world. [Yttrium]( (Y)
column2584: and [ytterbium]( (Yb) are all named after the village.\n\nOther elements including holmium
column2588: and thulium were first discovered there
column2589: making Ytterby the richest source of naturally occurring elements on Earth.\n\nBack in 1787
column2590: army lieutenant and part-time chemist Carl Axel Arrhenius discovered a strange
column2591: unusually heavy black ore in an old quarry near Ytterby. This new ore was named by Arrhenius as ytterbite.\n\nTwo years later
column2592: a Finnish chemist identified from Arrhenius’ initial sample the first rare earth element – named yttrium. In just over 50 years following Arrhenius’ original discovery
column2593: Carl Gustav Mosander found that ytterbite was actually a mixture of three metal oxides
column2594: and a fourth was later discovered by Jean Charles Galissard de Marignac from the original sample.\n\nEventually as refining techniques improved
column2595: more new elements were discovered and ultimately over the next 100 years since Arrhenius’ discovery
column2596: nine more elements fell out of this strange
column2597: unusually heavy black ore.\n\nAmong these hard-to-pronounce elements is yttrium – a soft
column2598: grey-white metal that is fairly stable in air but reacts with water
column2600: and bases.\n\nIt occurs in other ‘rare earth’ minerals
column2603: which is mined in China and Malaysia
column2604: can contain up to 50% yttrium phosphate
column2605: according to the Royal Society of Chemistry.\n\nYttrium metal is produced by reducing yttrium fluoride with calcium metal and is often used as an additive in alloys for its strengthening properties. When alloyed with aluminum
column2608: it acts to strengthen those metals.\n\nIn addition to its applications in speciality alloys found in engines
column2609: yttrium is used in coatings to shield against high temperatures.\n\nYttrium oxide is added to glass used to produce camera lenses as it makes them heat and shock resistant. It’s found in white LED lights as well as superconductors and lasers
column2610: with yttrium oxysulfide widely sought to produce red phosphors for old-style colour television tubes.\n\nLasers that can cut through metals require yttrium-aluminium garnet (YAG)
column2611: marking yet another of its many applications in everyday life.\n\nWhile its origins may come from Sweden
column2612: like other rare earths and critical minerals
column2613: China dominates global production and supply of yttrium. China supplies the US 93% of its yttrium imports
column2614: creating acute vulnerability across Western supply chains.\n\nThe world’s supplies are now running low due to Chinese export restrictions

column2704: The Rare Earth Metal Driving Tensions Between the US and China - WIRED
column2706: \"Yttrium plays a critical role in everything from aircraft engines to semiconductors. China controls the vast majority of the market—and that’s not changing anytime soon.\n\nThe alarm hasn't yet reached the general public
column2707: but tension is beginning to build in the corridors of the aerospace industry
column2709: and in government offices. For months
column2710: an element almost invisible to the world—yttrium—has become the silent center of a new global dispute. Supplies are thinning
column2712: deliveries are stalling. And while China and the United States have [promised a truce over rare earth minerals]( the wheels of advanced technology are beginning to slow.\n\nAlthough a late-October meeting in South Korea between Chinese president Xi Jinping and his US counterpart Donald Trump raised hopes for a détente
column2713: the [Chinese export restrictions]( introduced last April remain substantially in place. Beijing granted a one-year reprieve on the mandatory government licensing system for shipments of rare earths and products containing related materials (including those made abroad with at least 0.1 percent Chinese resources)
column2714: in exchange for a similar suspension of the White House's latest restrictions on technology supply chains.\n\nBut other measures introduced before the latest escalation remain in place. The result is a tightening of the international supply chain that threatens to slow advanced technological production
column2716: and challenge entire industrial sectors. Yttrium plays a crucial role in the functioning of contemporary technologies. Without yttrium
column2720: and semiconductors would immediately slow down.\n\nYttrium's value lies in its ability to impart thermal and mechanical strength to materials subjected to extreme temperatures. Jet engines blades
column2722: must withstand prolonged overheating and intense vibration; yttrium is what allows them to maintain structural integrity and efficiency. The same is true for industrial chip manufacturing
column2723: where yttrium-based coatings protect machinery from chemical wear and ensure precision in plasma etching. Its indispensable nature has made it a key element of modern technology and the military.\n\nThe problem is that
column2725: China controls almost the entire global yttrium supply chain. Not only does it produce most of it
column2726: but it also has the know-how and infrastructure to refine and separate it from other rare earth minerals
column2727: a complex and technologically advanced process. According to US data
column2728: the United States imports 100 percent of its yttrium needs
column2729: 93 percent of which comes directly from China. Such stark dependence creates enormous geopolitical vulnerability.\n\nWhen Beijing decided to introduce export restrictions as a response to US tariffs
column2730: the entire international supply structure began to falter. Companies reported delays
column2732: and uncertainty about delivery times. In the rare earths trade
column2733: lack of predictability is often more damaging than reduced volumes: An industry accustomed to just-in-time deliveries can be thrown into crisis by even a few weeks of delay.\n\nThe effects were immediate. In Europe
column2736: 400 percent increase since the beginning of the year. Aerospace companies
column2737: which rely heavily on this material
column2738: have expressed alarm and demanded urgent measures from the US government to expand domestic production. The semiconductor industry is no less concerned: Some companies have called the situation a “serious” threat
column2741: and production timelines. Gas-fired power plants
column2742: which use yttrium in the protective coatings of turbines

column2761: a sector in which China holds a leadership position that is unlikely to be replicated in the short term. This dual approach—control of physical resources and human capital—strengthens Chinese primacy and hampers attempts to build an alternative supply chain.\n\nThe United States is nevertheless trying to fight back. a crucial and potentially decisive negotiating lever.

” says Ilyubayeva.

column2854: Exploration funding reaches ‘turning point’ in Australia: report - Australian Mining
column2856: \"A new report suggests an “aggressive rush of capital” has hit Australia’s exploration sector as governments and investors move to strengthen and diversify critical mineral supply chains.\n\nThe *September quarterly cash update* report
column2857: released by professional services company BDO
column2858: shows $3.49 billion flowing into the sector as a result of investors and governments moving “more decisively” to [reinforce long-term critical minerals supply capabilities](\n\n“Australia’s traditional September fundraising slump did not materialise
column2859: with the quarter instead breaking a decade-long pattern of weakness
column2860:
” the report said.

The report marks the first time in four years that explorers have experienced consecutive quarterly [increases in funding]( – going against a “usual downturn” of cash inflow.

The quarter delivered an 81 per cent rise in funding from June
column2861: driven by 78 companies raising more than $10 million each and capturing $2.88 billion of the total inflow.\n\nThese positive numbers have been described as a turning point for exploration in Australia
column2862: with the race for strategic resources accelerating at a pace the market has not seen in years.\n\n“The scale of these raisings tells you exactly where global priorities are shifting
column2863: ” BDO global natural resources and energy leader Sherif Andrawes said.\n\n“Investors are backing assets that matter to energy security
column2864: electrification and industrial capability.”\n\nBoth copper and gold performed strongly in the quarter
column2866: with [gold remaining the largest contributor]( – 21 explorers are said to have raised over $500 million on the back of record gold prices and increased global demand.\n\n[Copper-linked companies]( are also said to have performed strongly
column2867: reflecting the metal’s central role in electrification.\n\nExploration spending climbed to $843.66 million
column2868: a 16 per cent rise driven by gold and copper explorers. Cash balances rose to an average of $11.02 million
column2869: the first lift in a year.\"
