column2941: 2 Monster Stocks to Hold for the Next 5 Years - The Motley Fool
column2943:
"* Multibagger stocks can grow your wealth exponentially.

* Niche players in high-potential industries can deliver monster returns over time.

* Robotics and rare earths are two such industries you'd want to look at right away.

These two stocks could skyrocket as they exploit their first-mover advantages in two massive industries.

Some stocks don't just outperform the broader markets -- they have the potential to deliver monumental returns over time
column2944: supercharging your portfolio for years to come. They're not hard to find if you know where to look. Such stocks with [multibagger]( potential are often hidden among leaders in fast-growing industries
column2945: first movers in industries with exponential potential
column2946:
and innovative start-ups that are shaping the future.

Two such stocks have caught my attention. Each has such compelling growth prospects that buying them now and holding them could yield monster returns over the next five years or so.

Image source: Getty Images.

Rare-earth elements technically aren't rare
column2947: but it's not easy to extract them in ways that are economically viable. China has a monopoly
column2948: accounting for almost 70% of the global rare-earth extraction. That also means [80% of the rare-earth elements consumed in the U.S.]( are imported
column2949: with nearly all of them coming from China.\n\nThat's not a great place to be. Rare-earth elements are vital for electronics
column2956: China's dominance poses significant supply risks to the U.S. Additionally
column2957: it has always disincentivized U.S. [mining]( companies from pouring money into rare-earth elements. President Donald Trump wants to change that and
column2959: has allocated billions of dollars to critical mineral projects
column2960: even buying stakes in some domestic producers to secure U.S. supply chains.\n\nThere is only one active rare-earth mine in the U.S.: the Mountain Pass in California
column2961: owned and operated by **MP Materials** ([MP](/quote/nyse/mp/) +2.99%).\n\nIn July 2025
column2963: rebranded as the Department of War (DOW) by Trump
column2964: acquired a 15% stake in MP Materials and became its largest shareholder. MP Materials will build a rare-earth magnet manufacturing facility
column2966:
with the DOW committing to purchase 100% of the rare-earth magnets produced at the facility for 10 years. Two of its other major deals include:

* A $500 million multiyear agreement with tech giant **Apple** ([AAPL](/quote/nasdaq/aapl/) +0.46%) to supply magnets.

* A partnership with the DOW and the Saudi Arabian Mining Company (Maaden) to develop a rare-earth refinery in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.

MP Materials currently produces rare-earth oxides and metals and will begin production of magnets by the end of 2025. [MP Materials stock already carries a market cap of $10 billion]( but that could look minuscule five years from now.

Shares of **Symbotic** ([SYM](/quote/nasdaq/sym/) 4.04%) have surged over 250% so far in 2025
column2967: as of this writing. And there could be a lot more to come.\n\nSymbotic automates warehouses and distribution centers with [artificial intelligence (AI)]( [robotics]( that can move
column2969: and sort items. Symbotic went public in 2022 but has been working with **Walmart** ([WMT](/quote/nyse/wmt/) +1.31%) since 2015 to deploy robotic systems at multiple distribution centers. In January 2025
column2970: Symbotic acquired Walmart's advanced systems and robotics (ASR) business for automated fulfillment of orders
column2971: a new product category for Symbotic.\n\nUnder yet another new and recent agreement
column2972: Symbotic will develop and install automated micro-fulfillment systems for online pickup and delivery at Walmart's retail stores. Symbotic expects its first prototype to be ready in 2026. Meanwhile
column2973: Symbotic is developing a next-generation storage technology as well. Besides Walmart
column2977: and **Target**.\n\nSymbotic has also just announced something big: It has signed up Medline as a customer
column2978: marking its foray into healthcare. [Medline is a major distributor of medical supplies]( in the U.S. and is expected to go public soon. Symbotic deployed its first system to Medline last quarter.\n\nSymbotic's entry into healthcare marks a significant milestone
column2979: as it opens up a new vertical for the company beyond retail and could fast-track its sales growth. Symbotic just posted a 26% growth in revenue for the fiscal year that ended Sept. 27
column2981: and projects similar growth for the first quarter of fiscal year 2026.\n\nMost importantly
column2982: Symbotic ended the year with a backlog of $22.5 billion. That's huge
column2983: as it represents nearly a decade's worth of sales. So
column2984: even though Symbotic's market cap has surpassed $50 billion
column2985: its estimated addressable market runs into the hundreds of billions of dollars
column2986: making it a solid stock to own for the long term.\n\nBoth MP Materials and Symbotic share a common link -- they have the first-mover advantage in their respective industries
column2987: *and* both industries have exponential growth potential. That's what makes these stocks so appealing. Growth stocks carry their share of risks
column2988: but with both Symbotic and MP Materials already generating revenue and striking significant partnerships
column2989: they're worth the risk.\n\nNeha Chamaria is a contributing Motley Fool stock market analyst covering energy
column2993: with a focus on dividend stocks. Prior to The Motley Fool
column2994: Neha worked on portfolio valuations for hedge funds at HSBC and authored articles as a journalist. She holds a master’s degree in finance from ICFAI and an MBA from Symbiosis University
column2995: along with certifications from the National Stock Exchange of India. Neha was honored with an all-India gold medal for her M.S. in Finance and was the first woman in her family to pursue a professional career.\n\nInvest better with The Motley Fool. Get stock recommendations
column2997: and more from The Motley Fool's premium services.\"

000m RC drill program (due to start in December) ahead of a “maiden resource in Q1-2026”.*

29 assays in the lab and 40 more holes planned... so we should see more good news like this week’s results over the coming weeks/months.*

**EIQ** has developed (and is already in the market with) an AI-powered algorithm that helps cardiologists detect heart diseases.

EIQ’s tech is already USA FDA approved AND being used by a growing number of hospitals in the USA to detect one heart disease called Aortic Stenosis.

**Earlier this week EIQ announced results of a clinical validation study on a different heart disease - Heart Failure.**

Heart Failure is one of the big heart diseases - US$60BN is spent on it
column3035:
and it's the leading cause of rehospitalisation.

EIQ’s clinical validation study was run by the prestigious Mayo Clinic. The study delivered exceptional results on **detecting heart failure with 99.5% sensitivity and 91.0% specificity** ([source](

Much better than the only other AI heart failure detection software used in the market today which delivers **sensitivity of 87.8% and specificity of 81.9%** ([source](

(Both technologies are a step change from current practices where only 50% of Heart Failure cases are accurately diagnosed.)

IF EIQ can get FDA approval for its Heart Failure AI model
column3036:
there already exists a reimbursement code the company can use to commercialise its AI tech.

The reimbursement code exists thanks to Ultromics (who [raised US$55M]( in a series C funding round valuing them at US$300M / A$464M back in July).

Now we watch for FDA clearance...

**IIQ** is developing an exosome platform technology.

IIQ is applying its exosome platform to develop diagnostics (detecting diseases) AND therapeutics (treating diseases).

Exosomes are tiny
column3037:
microscopic extra-cellular “containers” that carry ‘messages’ between the human body's cells that allows the human body to function.

**IIQ is going after two types of cancer that have NO approved/recommended treatments or diagnostic tools.**

* Ovarian cancer is usually asymptomatic (no symptoms) in the early stages of the disease. If a woman is diagnosed at stage 1 - the survival rates can be over 90%. If a woman is diagnosed at stages 3/4 survival rates can be ~29%. ~70% of all ovarian cancer in Australia is diagnosed as advanced [stage 3 or 4 cancer](

* At the moment there are no recommended screening tests for women who show no symptoms of ovarian cancer - meaning there is no quick and easy screening test that can be regularly taken by all healthy women to catch ovarian cancer early.

* **IIQ’s screening test has been able to detect all stage 1 and 2 ovarian cancers (the earliest but asymptomatic stages where survival rates are the highest)
column3038:
with over 99.6% specificity (catching 99.6% of all patients with cancer) AND NO misdiagnosis.**

* **What’s Next:** IIQ to do a larger clinical validation study (to see if the test works on a larger cohort of patients) then look at “strategic partnering” to commercialise the screening tool.

* Triple negative breast cancer is an aggressive type of breast cancer that does NOT respond to traditional breast cancer therapies.

* At the moment
column3039:
there are no approved cell therapies treating triple negative breast cancer.

* IIQ is developing the therapeutic under a deal signed with the prestigious Peter MacCallum Cancer Centre (Peter Mac) in Melbourne. The institution is among only a handful globally that combines a dedicated cancer hospital with a fully integrated cancer research program.

* **So far IIQ has shown that its therapeutic was able to kill more than 90% of the cancer cells within 10 hours of treatment in in vitro studies (in a laboratory setting).**

* **What’s next:** Next for the therapeutic is the results from animal studies (in-vivo) due this quarter.

We think that any solid tumour therapeutic IIQ is able to develop could be a game changer for the company.

Mainly because it would de-risk IIQ’s platform tech (if it works for one cancer

[Elon Musk]( has shared a new
column3269:
alarming video on social media that paints a world where humanoid robots slide into nearly every corner of our daily lives.

The clip features [Tesla's Optimus robot]( performing tasks ranging from physical labor to cooking. Musk paired the video with a sweeping promise that robots will raise global wealth and make work optional.

Get my best tech tips
column3270: urgent security alerts and exclusive deals delivered straight to your inbox. Plus
column3271: you’ll get instant access to my Ultimate Scam Survival Guide — free when you join my ***CYBERGUY.COM*** newsletter.\n\nA Tesla Optimus robot hands out candy in front of the Nasdaq MarketSite in New York
column3275: 2025. (Michael Nagle/Bloomberg via Getty Images)\n\nMusk reposted the 38-second video on his X profile
column3276: which was originally created by Alex Utopia and shows Tesla's humanoid robots doing a variety of everyday jobs. Since Musk posted the clip
column3277: it has racked up over 58.5 million views.\n\nThe montage shows Optimus walking down the street. It then cuts to a construction site where the robot supports workers. The clip shifts to a scene of Optimus providing emergency aid during a disaster drill. Next
column3278: you see Optimus inside a judo gym
column3280: the robot appears on an urban police patrol. The tone shifts again when Optimus lands in a casino dealing cards at a blackjack table. Then you can see it walking on the beach
column3281:
and then it is shown in a restaurant kitchen where it cooks a meal with professional chefs. The final shot shows Optimus back in a casino at a roulette table.

Musk has already shown Optimus folding laundry and walking in earlier demos. He continues to frame [humanoid robots]( as the solution for labor shortages tied to declining fertility rates.

An Optimus humanoid robot showcased at the Tesla booth at the 8th CIIE in Shanghai
column3283: 2025.  (CFOTO/Future Publishing via Getty Images)\n\nShortly after sharing the video
column3284: Musk spoke at the U.S.-Saudi Investment Forum
column3285: where he argued that humanoid robots will reshape society. According to Musk
column3286: work will shift from a necessity to a hobby. He compared future jobs to gardening for fun rather than buying vegetables at a store.\n\nMusk said he expects money to lose relevance as [artificial intelligence]( and robotics advance. He also claimed humanoid robots will become the biggest product in history. In his view
column3287:
there is one clear path to universal wealth. He said AI and robotics can eliminate poverty and allow people to choose work only when it brings joy.

Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang offered a more cautious perspective. He agreed that jobs will change but noted that currency will continue to matter for the foreseeable future.

The Tesla Bot humanoid robot of Tesla ""Optimus"" is displayed at the 2023 World Artificial Intelligence Conference in Shanghai
column3290: 2023. (CFOTO/Future Publishing via Getty Images)\n\nThe world Elon Musk describes raises big questions about daily life. Robots that can cook
column3291: build and respond to emergencies could reshape our communities. They may also transform what people see as valuable work. Even if full robot integration is years away
column3292: companies like Tesla are already starting to show how quickly this tech can evolve. You may not see an Optimus on your street yet
column3294: and the pace is fast.\n\nThink your devices and data are truly protected? Take this quick quiz to see where your digital habits stand. From passwords to Wi-Fi settings
column3295: you’ll get a personalized breakdown of what you’re doing right and what needs improvement. Take my Quiz here: ***Cyberguy.com.***\n\nMusk's reposted montage video has pushed the conversation about humanoid robots into sharper focus. The video shows how close companies like Tesla want us to be to a future filled with robots that move
column3296: react and work alongside us. The reactions range from excitement to real concern
column3297: which shows how uneasy many feel about a world shaped by machines that can cook
column3298:
patrol and even respond to emergencies. The speed of this progress is hard to ignore. Each new video hints at a future where robots handle more daily tasks and take on work that once needed human hands. Whether that future feels promising or unsettling will depend on how we prepare for it and how much control we keep as this technology grows.

How would you feel if a robot like Optimus began taking on tasks in your daily life? Let us know by writing to us at ***Cyberguy.com.***

The pitch from 1X is that Neo can do all manner of household chores: fold laundry
column3445: tidy shelves and bring in the groceries. It can open doors
column3446: climb stairs and even act as a home entertainment system.\n\nNeo appears to move smoothly
column3449: thanks to 1X's tendon-driven motor system that gives it gentle motion and impressive strength. The company says it can lift up to 154 pounds and carry 55 pounds
column3450: but it is quieter than a refrigerator. It's covered in soft materials and neutral colors
column3451: making it look less intimidating than metallic prototypes from other companies.\n\nThe company says Neo has a 4-hour runtime. Its hands are IP68-rated
column3452: meaning they're submersible in water. It can connect via Wi-Fi
column3454: it has a built-in large language model (LLM)
column3455: the same sort of [AI technology](/tech/services-and-software/best-ai-chatbots/) that powers [ChatGPT](/tech/services-and-software/what-is-chatgpt-everything-you-need-to-know-about-the-ai-chatbot/) and [Gemini](/tech/services-and-software/what-is-gemini-everything-you-should-know-about-googles-ai-tool/).\n\nThe primary way to control the Neo robot will be by speaking to it
column3456: just as if it were a person.\n\nStill
column3457: Neo's usefulness today depends heavily on how you define useful. The Wall Street Journal's Joanna Stern got an [up-close look at Neo]( at 1X's headquarters and found that
column3460: meaning a human often operates it remotely using a [virtual-reality headset](/news/best-vr-headset-sem/) and controllers.\n\n\"\"I didn't see Neo do anything autonomously
column3461: although the company did share a video of Neo opening a door on its own
column3462: \"\" Stern wrote last week. 1X CEO Bernt Børnich reportedly told her that Neo will do most things autonomously in 2026
column3463: though he also acknowledged that the quality \"\"may lag at first.\"\"\n\nThe company's FAQ says that if there's a chore request Neo doesn't know how to accomplish
column3464: you can schedule an expert from 1X to help the robot \"\"learn while getting the job done.\"\"\n\nPart of what early adopters are signing up for is to allow Neo to learn from their environment
column3465: so that future versions can operate more independently.\n\nThat learning process raises questions about privacy and trust. The robot uses a mix of visual
column3466: audio and contextual intelligence -- meaning it can see
column3467: hear and remember interactions with you in your home.\n\n\"\"If you buy this product
column3468: it is because you're OK with that social contract
column3469: \"\" Børnich told the Journal. \"\"It's less about Neo instantly doing your chores and more about you helping Neo learn to do them safely and effectively.\"\"\n\nNeo's reliance on human operation behind the scenes prompted a response from John Carmack
column3470: a computer industry luminary known for his work with VR systems and the lead programmer of classic video games
column3471: including Doom and Quake.\n\n\"\"Companies selling the dream of autonomous household humanoid robots today would be better off embracing reality and selling 'remote operated household help'
column3472: \"\" he wrote in a [post on the X social network](\n\n1X says it's taking steps to protect your privacy: Neo listens only when it recognizes it's being addressed
column3473: and its cameras will blur out humans. You can restrict Neo from entering or viewing specific areas of your home
column3474: and the robot will never be teleoperated without owner approval
column3475:
the company says.

But inviting an AI-equipped humanoid to observe your home life isn't a small step.

The first units are expected to ship to customers in the US in 2026. There is a $499 monthly subscription alternative to the $20
column3477:
although it will be available at an unspecified later date. A broader international rollout is promised for 2027.

Neo's got a long road ahead of it to live up to the expectations set by Rosie the Robot in The Jetsons way back when. But this is no Hanna-Barbera cartoon. What we're seeing now is a much more tangible harbinger of change.

column3641: Petersen Museum's Newest Exhibit Showcases Iconic Off-Road Racers - Car and Driver
column3643:
"**New!**Shop For Cars Available Near You.

Got it!

Called 'Legends of the Dirt
column3644: ' it includes a classic Bronco Baja winner and possibly the craziest Suzuki hatchback of all time.\n\n*   **There's a classic Bronco Baja winner
column3646: and possibly the craziest Suzuki hatchback of all time.**\n\nWhile the Petersen Automotive Museum is otherwise a glittering collection of gleaming sheetmetal on polished floors
column3647: its latest exhibition is all about getting mud on your boots. Dubbed \"\"Legends of the Dirt
column3648: the exhibit features some of the greatest off-road racing machines from the Baja 1000
column3650: and the World Rally Championship.\n\nFrom the latter
column3652: the last rear-wheel-drive car to hold its own against the onslaught of all-wheel-drive machines in WRC racing. Driven by Finn Markku Alén and Walter Röhrl (perhaps better known for his exploits racing for Audi)
column3653: this car won Lancia the Constructor's title in 1983. Every winning driver since then has been in an AWD machine.\n\nSpeaking of all-wheel drive
column3654: few machines are nuttier than the 1993 Suzuki Cultus Pikes Peak Special. You may remember this subcompact hatchback as the Suzuki Swift or Pontiac Firefly (or even the Geo Metro
column3656: which ordinarily had front-wheel drive and no more than 100 hp. This example has almost eight times as much.\n\nRaced at the Pikes Peak International Hillclimb by the affable Nouhiro \"\"Monster\"\" Tajima—and by thousands of youngsters in _Gran Turismo 2_—this hugely winged hatchback makes its power through a turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine mounted up front. And
column3658: a second turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine in the rear. That's a lot of motor for one little car
column3659: especially one that tips the scales at less than 2000 pounds.\n\nThe Petersen will also be featuring a number of significant off-road racing trucks
column3660: including the 1995 Herbst \"\"Landshark.\"\" A SCORE International Class 1 desert racer
column3661: this custom-built off-roader was a game changer when it arrived on the sands in the mid-1990s
column3662: a cross between a traditional buggy-style Baja racer and the toughness of a truck.\n\nOther Baja legends include the 1970 Bronco \"\"Big Oly\"\" as driven by Parnelli Jones to two consecutive Baja 1000 wins (1971 and 1972). It looks like a Bronco on the outside
column3663: but it's a custom tube chassis underneath with a partially composite body. Like any good dune racer
column3664: it loves to fly.\n\nOther notable examples on display include the first King of the Hammers-winning Ford Bronco Ultra4
column3665: a 2010 Coleworks rock bouncer made for extreme vertical climbing
column3666: and a Global Rallycross Volkswagen Beetle GRC. Alongside these will be a collection of historically significant off-road racing motorcycles
column3667: along with displays explaining how off-road tech works.\n\nThis is the first time the Petersen has really gone big into an off-roading display
column3668: so if you're a fan of low-flying Fords taking to the skies above the Baja peninsula
column3669:
you're going to want to schedule a visit. The exhibit opens on December 7 and runs right through January 2027. And they won't even make you wipe your feet before they let you in.

column3713:
"* ‘Rich Dad Poor Dad’ author drops worrying take on stock market.

* He urges buying into 'God's Money' and digital money.

* Kiyosaki's past crash predictions often failed to materialize but the market debate continues.

“**Rich Dad Poor Dad**” author Robert Kiyosaki just fired off a massive headline-grabbing warning.

The popular financial commentator says that the “biggest crash in history” is already underway
column3715: but not entirely an ill-founded one
column3716: according to [reporting from MoneyWise](\n\nIt comes at a moment when the [S&P 500]( is hovering near record highs
column3717: yet investor worries about an [AI]( bubble remain the elephant in the room.\n\nFor perspective
column3726: pointing to AI-driven [layoffs]( global economic jitters
column3727: and what he calls an imminent collapse in both residential and commercial real estate.\n\nIn typical Kiyosaki fashion
column3728: his calls are blunt and apocalyptic
column3729: but they inevitably spark fleshed-out debates among stock-market pundits.\n\nRobert Kiyosaki is a popular businessman-turned-financial guru
column3730: behind the smash-hit 1997 personal finance book “Rich Dad Poor Dad.”\n\nThe book and its spin-offs have collectively sold [**over 32 million copies**]( globally and have been translated into dozens of languages
column3731: remaining on bestseller lists for years.\n\nSince then
column3732: he’s built an empire of sorts around the Rich Dad brand
column3736: Kiyosaki has authored over a couple of dozen books
column3737: positioning himself as one of the most popular investors and financial educators of all time.\n\nHis investing mantra primarily leans on [leveraged]( real estate
column3740: and major positions in what he deems “God’s money” (gold and silver)
column3743: estimates from *Celebrity Net Worth* peg his [personal wealth at $100 million]( though he’s bragged about being “**over $1 billion in debt**” by design.\n\nRobert Kiyosaki is back at it
column3744: saying that a historic market meltdown is underway.\n\nAs per reporting from *MoneyWise*
column3745: the “Rich Dad Poor Dad” author posted [a dire message on X]( declaring the “BIGGEST CRASH IN HISTORY STARTING.”\n\nMoreover
column3746: he goes on to argue that the downturn isn’t just limited to the U.S. stock market
column3747: but also notes that Europe and Asia are showing signs of strain
column3748: as AI continues to threaten the loss of millions of jobs.\n\nAdditionally
column3751: commercial and residential real estate will follow suit.\n\nHowever
column3752: Kiyosaki feels the moment can be both a disaster and an opportunity.\n\nMillions may “lose everything
column3753:
” but he argues that those who position themselves correctly will come out on the other side.

His playbook is essentially the same one that he’s been promoting for years.

Buy more gold
column3756: and Ethereum.\n\nHe has even attached some ambitious price targets
column3757: predicting that gold could potentially jump to $27
column3760: he feels silver might turn out to be the biggest winner of them all
column3761: potentially skyrocketing toward the $200 mark by 2026.\n\nTo be fair
column3762:
Kiyosaki isn’t the only one spelling out their worries over an AI bubble.

* **[Michael Burry]( (“The Big Short”)**: Has [over a $1 billion bet]( against [Nvidia]( and [Palantir]( via [put options](

* **[Jamie Dimon]( (JPMorgan CEO)**: Says some AI names are already in “bubble territory
column3763:
” while praising the technology’s long-term potential.

* **Howard Marks (Oaktree Capital)**: Tied today’s AI/Big Tech euphoria to previous manias such as the late-’90s internet stocks.

* **[Stanley Druckenmiller]( (billionaire [hedge fund]( legend)**: Dumped Nvidia and Palantir entirely
column3764:
locking in gains.

* **Peter Thiel (Thiel Macro / Palantir co-founder):** Thiel Macro’s Q3 13F shows he [exited his entire Nvidia stake](  roughly $100 million worth.

Kiyosaki isn’t new to making dire predictions.

For over a decade
column3765: the best-selling author has been issuing sweeping warnings about the stock market’s collapse
column3767:
and runaway [inflation](

One move from JPMorgan has traders rethinking what comes next.

His track record
column3769: has been mostly uneven. Some of them tapped into real anxieties
column3770: while others tell a very different story.\n\n* **The long-running “Rich Dad’s Prophecy” crash (2016):** Kiyosaki spent years warning investors that baby boomer retirements could potentially trigger the “biggest crash in history.”  By 2016
column3771: he argued that the collapse had begun
column3772: blaming China’s slowdown and “Fed insanity.” However
column3775: not in shambles as he predicted.\n\n* **The Covid crash that “would keep going” (April 2020):** In the height of the pandemic panic
column3776: he laid out that the crash was far from over
column3780: the S&P 500 ended up posting [nearly a 27% gain]( in 2021.\n\n* **The 2021–2022 “giant crash” and “everything crash”:** [He forecasted an October 2021 wipeout]( warning that stocks
column3782: and crypto could potentially collapse together. Stocks dipped modestly
column3783: but Bitcoin and silver dropped significantly more. Over the following year
column3784: markets continued to post stronger gains.\n\n* **Hyperbolic targets for gold
column3789: 000 and [Bitcoin near $1 million]( his calls continue to point northward. Nonetheless
column3791:
markets are nowhere in that vicinity.

Here’s what could happen to Nvidia shares next.

they can’t even ride bikes.”

column4013: \"What you get with the stripped-down Model Y and Model 3.\n\nTesla has launched a range of more affordable [electric cars](/home/electric-vehicles/best-ev-electric-car/) -- stripped-back versions of the [refreshed Model Y](/home/electric-vehicles/teslas-model-y-redesign-has-arrived-but-maybe-not-where-you-are/) and [Model 3](/home/electric-vehicles/tesla-model-3-refreshed-with-new-look-longer-range/). column4015: I see it as a move that could significantly boost Tesla ownership.\n\nThe idea is simple: Make the same design and driving experience accessible to more people by eliminating the extras that most owners rarely use. In my view

while the rear ones are not.

column4235: Many Green Shipping Corridors Stalled - Marine News Magazine
column4238: Inc.\n\nA new report from the Getting to Zero Coalition identifies 25 new green shipping corridors – trade routes designed to demonstrate and scale novel zero-emission fuels
column4240: and technologies – launched this last year
column4241: expanding the global total to 84 active initiatives.\n\n[At a Crossroads: Annual Progress Report on Green Shipping Corridors 2025]( reveals that new initiatives have been launched in major developing economies like China
column4246: and Kenya.\n\nFor the first time since the report’s inception in 2022
column4247: four corridors have now reached the ‘realization stage’ where construction and operation begin to take place. However
column4248: many corridors remain stalled by a 'feasibility wall' created by the cost gap between conventional and zero-emission fuels.\n\nThere are now over 300 stakeholders involved in green corridors
column4249: up from 240 in the previous edition. Port authorities continue to be key leaders
column4250: with public sector and governmental actors following closely behind them. The vessel owner/operator category increased by over 30% since last year
column4251: which could indicate that port and government-led initiatives are having more success finding partners in shipping. The one category with no positive movement on the stakeholder side is financial institutions. This could be due to engagement with financiers occurring outside the core green corridor consortia.\n\nThis year’s findings also reveal that some government-funded initiatives have stalled after feasibility studies have been completed
column4252: suggesting a gap between government priorities and industry interests. While companies have leveraged government funding to explore fuel options and thereby reduce their in-house research costs
column4253: this has not yielded action in many cases. In contrast
column4254: initiatives with high industry involvement have been progressing the fastest
column4255: as indicated by the four green corridors now in the realization stage.\n\nOut of the 84 initiatives in this year’s edition
column4257: 44 (16 early and 28 advanced) are in Exploration
column4259: and four are in Realization. Additionally

column4303: The Strange Time Compression of Sodium-Ion Battery Development - CleanTechnica
column4305: \"If you are not aware of Chinese battery technical leadership
column4306: it is probably time to take notice. As of 2025
column4307: [CATL and BYD]( have over 50% of the world’s EV battery market share. From January to September
column4308: they accounted for 811.7 GWh. CATL and BYD are not the only battery companies in China. In total
column4311: up 44% from the previous year.\n\nWhile the two giants have specialized in LFP and NMC batteries
column4312: relatively small Beijing HiNa concentrated on sodium-ion batteries (SIB) used in [JAC]( cars and in other areas
column4313: including [utility storage](\n\nHiNa’s inroads have made waves and reverberated throughout the industry. Competition is strong. Sodium-ion batteries have been under development for many years
column4314: with a field of competitors globally. [HiNa]( was founded in 2017
column4315: and produced sodium-ion batteries from its GWh class factory since November 29
column4316: 2022. What is interesting here is that HiNa seems to be lighting a fire under the competitors. HiNa introduced sodium-ion to the utility storage market
column4317: providing product for the world’s largest sodium-ion storage system ([a 100 MWh system]( in Nanning
column4320: the first stage of a planned 200 MWh system.\n\nThe two largest players are not standing still. BYD broke ground on construction of a 30 GWh sodium-ion factory in January of 2024 and announced sodium-ion products. BYD announced its [MC Cube-SIB]( product
column4321: a containerized battery energy storage unit for the utility storage market. BYD has claimed that its system could reduce costs below the HiNa system costs of [$ 0.03/kWh]( CATL’s first-generation sodium-ion battery was released in 2021
column4326: with operation from -40°C to 70°C and 90% energy retention at -40°C
column4327: offering 500 km (310 miles) of range.\n\nWhile Chinese battery companies announce and ship products
column4328: sources claim sodium-ion batteries need further development to compete with LFP. A [Stanford analysis]( early this year of sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) stated that energy density was lower than lithium competitors and would restrain advancement without research breakthroughs. This analysis was picked up and amplified on [social media]( The social media source has an excellent description of SIB operation and technical details
column4329: some of which are from SIB researcher and expert [Shirley Meng]( While the warnings of other social media overheated claims are real
column4332: and HiNa Haixing commercial battery announcements seem to contradict the slower rollout expectations. By some measures
column4333: those products meet [parity]( [with LFP]( The SIB products are there and perform well compared to LFP
column4334: with similar gravimetric energy density and cycle life
column4336: SIB has superior energy retention at cold temperatures. The expectation in other quarters is that SIB will start to replace LFP. The question remains how much SIB will be produced and when.\n\nWhile the social media fracas has created a flurry of SIB interest and some hype
column4337: the real question is what happens next. With considerable investment in sodium-ion battery factories and new product
column4338: there is pressure to sell product. Sources agree that the initial best fit for the technology is grid storage
column4339: where density is not a factor. There is motivation to build production volume and use that to lower cost.\n\nThe pressure of sodium ion advancement is starting to be felt globally. In Korea
column4340: the warning is that battery companies there could lose market share if they do not adopt [sodium]( technology. [LG Chem]( has partnered with Sinopec to develop sodium-ion batteries. Korean battery companies rely heavily on NMC. The BYD Blade battery system showed that LFP can compete with NMC in EVs because it can fit more densely in battery packs
column4341: making up some of the difference with NMC. Because of this
column4342: LFP batteries are now appearing in some western cars like the [Chevy]( [Bolt]( and recently were in entry-level Teslas. Now SIB are expected to further undercut LFP prices
column4343: spurring the two largest battery companies to advance SIB and LG Chem to develop SIBs.\n\nAt the very least
column4344: the word in China is that in 2027
column4345: the [cost]( of SIB is expected to move toward $0.04/kWh prices typical of LFP. Given lower SIB material and production costs
column4347: no one will want to be left behind as the inevitable shift to SIB becomes evident.\n\nThe natural progression of battery developments is that at first
column4348: only one of a few chemistries can meet application demands
column4349: then after the first chemistry does so
column4351: lower performance chemistries continually advance until they meet minimum requirements. When that happens
column4352: the leading chemistry moves up to a higher cost tier with more stringent applications.\n\nThis has happened several times before in EVs
column4355: each supplanting the other at lower costs as the newer entrants advance
column4357: and get closer to theoretical performance. While lithium has been dominant for more than a decade
column4358: advancements in other chemistries have been expected for many years
column4359: with pressure on for lower costs
column4361: and safety. Because of the nature of development and application needs at threshold requirements
column4362: advancements tend to go unnoticed until threshold requirements are reached. So it was with solar as well
column4364: it was always too expensive. Then suddenly it wasn’t. It quickly passed parity with fossil fuel generation
column4365: and only hydro is cheaper now. The pace in battery chemistry advancements appears slower than semiconductors or solar
column4367: and with the level of volume and capital involved now
column4368: the necessary investment in research is now producing fruit.\n\nYou can be sure further advances will take place
column4369: and each step in advancement causes changes in application. Lithium has opened the market for EVs and grid storage. SIB will push open the market for long-distance electric ships and all ships in general. SIBs will bring electrification market penetration to new levels and new large-scale application
column4370: with costs that will sweep away remaining questions of renewable economics and add further pressure to car companies to switch to EVs
column4371: cementing batteries as the lowest cost choice. The signs that ICE (internal combustion engine) parity is reached are apparent
column4372: with the auto companies waving a [white flag]( pleading for tariffs building an artificial moat against change that will inevitably succumb to progress. Their calls for protectionism belie years of EV development neglect. The changes already happening with solar
column4374:
and EVs will quicken pace and the cycle will repeat as further market adoption leads to further investment in cleantech. The economic excuses are melting away as the losers clinging to fossil fuels get left behind.

2025 | 8:26 am  [Battery Metals]( [Top Companies]( [China]( [Latin America]( [Lithium](

Tianqi Lithium Corp. chief executive officer Frank Ha is keeping the door open to the possibility of taking a case against Chile’s SQM to an international tribunal.

The Chinese company
column4387: has been arguing that a deal to give state-owned Codelco majority ownership in SQM’s prized Atacama lithium in exchange for three more decades of operations should have [gone to a shareholder vote](\n\n“The treatment we have currently received in this process is undoubtedly frustrating for us as a minority international shareholder
column4388: ” Ha wrote in written responses to *Bloomberg* questions. Tianqi doesn’t rule out filing for international arbitration
column4389: he said.\n\nTianqi’s [fight for a say]( in a transaction involving one of the world’s biggest and most profitable lithium operations has endured [a series of setbacks in Chile]( with authorities there clearing the deal to go through with just boardroom approval. Last week the Chinese firm
column4391: filed an appeal with Chile’s supreme court.\n\n“This is a matter of corporate governance standards
column4392:
” Ha wrote. “This is unrelated to the identity of the partner.”

The SQM-Codelco partnership is a pillar of Chilean President [Gabriel Boric’s agenda]( to have more state control in key lithium assets while boosting output in the transition away from fossil fuels.

The deal marks Codelco’s entry into lithium production
column4393: with the state company set to own 50% of shares plus one after 2030. Until then
column4394: SQM will retain operational control.\n\nEarlier this month
column4395: China’s antitrust agency [granted conditional approval]( for the partnership
column4396: saying the companies must honor existing commercial commitments and continue supplying Chinese customers on a “fair
column4397:
reasonable and non-discriminatory” basis.

Tianqi’s Ha said SQM’s stake remains an important investment and that no decision had been made with regards to its sale.

“Any future decisions will be based on comprehensive financial
column4400: fully taking into account the interests of shareholders and stakeholders
column4401: ” he wrote.\n\nExecuting a transaction that changes control of a listed company’s major asset without shareholder approval “sets a precedent that all international investors must take seriously
column4402:
” Ha wrote. Tianqi remains confident that “Chile has the capacity to strengthen and maintain the governance standards.”

column4491: Airbus A320 Software Recall: How Airlines Raced to Fix a Solar‑Radiation Glitch and Averted Global Travel Chaos - ts2.tech
column4493: \"# Airbus A320 Software Recall: How Airlines Raced to Fix a Solar‑Radiation Glitch and Averted Global Travel Chaos\n\nAirlines around the world have spent the last 48 hours racing to patch a critical software vulnerability on thousands of Airbus A320‑family jets after regulators warned that intense solar radiation could corrupt flight‑control data. As of Sunday
column4496: 000 affected aircraft are back in service
column4497: and fears of a full‑blown holiday travel meltdown have largely eased.  [[1]](\n\nThe emergency recall was triggered by an October 30 incident in which a JetBlue A320 flying from Cancún to Newark suddenly pitched down without pilot command
column4498: injuring passengers and forcing an emergency diversion to Tampa. Investigators later traced the problem to a software update in a key flight‑control computer that appears vulnerable to “bit flips” caused by intense bursts of solar energy.  [[2]](\n\n* **Scale:** About **6
column4499:
000 A320‑family jets** – a little over half the global fleet – were flagged for urgent checks and fixes.  [[3]](

* **Root cause:** A recent software update to the **elevator aileron computer (ELAC)** created a rare vulnerability where **intense solar radiation** can corrupt critical flight‑control data.  [[4]](

* **Regulatory response:** Europe’s aviation regulator **EASA** issued an **Emergency Airworthiness Directive (AD 2025‑0268‑E)** on November 28
column4500: mandating repairs before affected aircraft carry passengers again.  [[5]](\n\n* **Fix strategy:** Around **5
column4501: 100 jets** simply reverted to an earlier software version; about **900 older aircraft** need flight‑computer hardware changes
column4502: which take longer.  [[6]](\n\n* **Disruption:** Hundreds of flights were cancelled or delayed worldwide
column4503: with **Asia‑Pacific and Latin America** hit hardest
column4504: but major hubs avoided gridlock and US Thanksgiving traffic largely held up.  [[7]](\n\n* **Industry impact:** Analysts estimate **$2–3 billion in lost revenue for airlines**
column4507: when a JetBlue A320 en route from Cancún to Newark suffered a sudden
column4508: uncommanded nose‑down maneuver at cruise altitude. The pilots recovered control and diverted to **Tampa
column4510: where at least 10–15 passengers were treated for injuries from the abrupt descent.  [[9]](\n\nEarly analysis suggested the aircraft’s **elevator aileron computer (ELAC)** – the system that translates pilots’ side‑stick inputs into movements of the elevators and ailerons
column4511: controlling the jet’s pitch and roll – had briefly acted on corrupted data.  [[10]](\n\nAirbus later told airlines and regulators that a **recent ELAC software update**
column4512: originally designed to bolster protections against loss‑of‑control events
column4513:
may have inadvertently opened a tiny but serious window where **“intense” solar radiation**can flip bits in the computer’s memory at just the wrong moment.  [[11]](

This kind of phenomenon – known in avionics and chip engineering as a **single‑event upset** – isn’t new. Modern aircraft are designed with extensive redundancy and safety margins to cope with cosmic rays and solar storms. What’s new here is that the specific software logic introduced earlier this year appears to have made one of those ultra‑rare bit flips capable of generating an **uncommanded flight‑control input**.

Once that risk was identified
column4514:
Airbus issued an **Alert Operators Transmission (AOT)** and worked with EASA to turn it into a **legally binding Emergency Airworthiness Directive** requiring operators to apply fixes before their next passenger flight.  [[12]](

## How many jets are affected – and where?

The A320 family – including the older **A320ceo** and the newer **A320neo** variants – is the **world’s most widely used single‑aisle jet**
column4515: the backbone of short‑ and medium‑haul flying from low‑cost carriers to legacy giants.  [[13]](\n\n* About **6
column4516: 000 aircraft** worldwide needed checks and updates
column4517: roughly **half the active A320 fleet**.  [[14]](\n\n* The affected aircraft are spread across **Europe
column4522: operated by hundreds of airlines from budget carriers to flagships.  [[15]](\n\n* In **Japan**
column4526:
as it worked through software updates on 34 A320‑series jets.  [[16]](

* **Colombia’s Avianca** says about **70% of its fleet** is impacted; it has **halted ticket sales until December 8** and warned of significant disruption for at least ten days.  [[17]](

* In **Australia and New Zealand**
column4527: Jetstar cancelled about **90 flights** on Saturday alone
column4528: while Air New Zealand dropped **27 flights** as they completed updates; both expect normal schedules to resume early this week.  [[18]](\n\nIn **India**
column4529: up to **200–250 A320‑family aircraft** across IndiGo
column4530: Air India and others were flagged. However
column4531: IndiGo reports that mandatory updates have already been completed on most of its affected fleet
column4532: with minimal cancellations.  [[19]](\n\nDespite alarm about potential chaos over **US Thanksgiving weekend**
column4533: the impact in North America has been relatively modest:\n\n* **American
column4534: Delta and United** all reported that they either completed or nearly completed the required fixes without major schedule changes.  [[20]](\n\n* The main exception has been **JetBlue**
column4535: which operates a heavily Airbus‑based fleet and had to cancel roughly **70 flights** as it cycled aircraft through updates.  [[21]](\n\nIn Europe
column4536: carriers such as **Lufthansa** and **easyJet** say most updates were completed overnight with only isolated delays
column4537:
rather than mass cancellations.  [[22]](

## What exactly went wrong in the A320 software?

On a modern Airbus
column4538: the pilot’s movements on the **side‑stick** don’t directly move cables and pulleys. They’re turned into digital commands
column4539:
processed by a set of redundant computers (including the **elevator aileron computers**) which then drive actuators on the control surfaces.

1. **Monitors sensor inputs** such as angle‑of‑attack (AoA) and pitch rate.

2. **Cross‑checks data** between multiple channels to detect anomalies.

3. **Applies automatic protections** – for example
column4540: avoiding a stall by pushing the nose down if it believes the aircraft is at too high an angle of attack.  [[23]](\n\nAccording to FlightGlobal and other specialist outlets
column4541: the software revision was meant to enhance protection against loss‑of‑control events – but under a narrow set of conditions
column4542: a solar‑induced bit flip can cause the system to misinterpret data and briefly command a **nose‑down input the pilots did not request**.  [[24]](\n\n* **Revert to the prior
column4543:
proven software version** that does not contain the vulnerable logic.

* Run checks to confirm the ELAC hardware is functioning properly.

This is typically a **2–3 hour job per aircraft**
column4544: often performed overnight or in off‑peak windows.  [[25]](\n\nHowever
column4545: around **900 older A320‑family jets** use a generation of computers that require **physical hardware replacement** rather than just a software rollback. Those aircraft face longer outages measured in days
column4547: and are driving much of the lingering disruption in markets such as Latin America and parts of Asia.  [[26]](\n\nOnce EASA’s emergency directive became effective on **November 29**
column4548:
airlines faced a harsh requirement: **no passenger flights on affected A320s until the fix is in**.  [[27]](

* **Pre‑cancelling** a block of flights to free up maintenance slots.

* **Reassigning other aircraft types** (such as Boeing 737s or wide‑body jets) to cover the most critical routes.

* Many major hubs were reporting **near‑normal traffic flows**
column4549: with delays measured in minutes rather than hours.  [[29]](\n\n* Airbus said airlines had made “rapid progress” and reiterated that safety was the overriding priority
column4550: even as it apologized for the disruption.  [[30]](\n\nSmaller and more regionally concentrated airlines
column4551: especially those with fleets heavily skewed toward older A320s
column4554: has suspended ticket sales for over a week and expects **ongoing disruption** as it cycles aircraft through hardware changes.  [[31]](\n\n* Some **Philippine and Indian carriers** have grounded dozens of flights while updates are completed
column4555:
offering refunds and free rebooking.  [[32]](

This uneven impact highlights a structural divide: global network giants can shuffle aircraft types and spare capacity; smaller or low‑cost carriers that bet heavily on a single family – often the A320 – have fewer levers to pull when the unexpected happens.

## Are A320s safe to fly now?

For passengers
column4556:
the most important point is that **regulators are not allowing unfixed aircraft to carry paying customers**. The EASA directive and parallel actions by other authorities require operators to verify that each aircraft’s ELAC meets the new safety standard before it returns to service.  [[33]](

* The underlying risk **remains extremely rare**; it appears tied to a combination of a specific software logic path and unusual bursts of solar activity.  [[34]](

* Affected jets are either **grounded for modification** or have already had the fix applied. Airlines have strong incentives – regulatory
column4557:
reputational and financial – to take this directive seriously.  [[35]](

* Airbus and regulators continue to investigate the JetBlue incident and other data to understand whether additional long‑term software or hardware changes will be needed.  [[36]](

For travelers booked in the coming days
column4558: the practical advice is simple: **monitor your flight status closely** and expect occasional last‑minute aircraft swaps or minor delays
column4559: especially on carriers that rely heavily on older A320s.\n\nEarly estimates suggest airlines could absorb **$2–3 billion in lost revenue and extra costs**
column4563: and passenger compensation where applicable.  [[37]](\n\n* **Airbus shares fell** after the recall became public
column4565: retrofit costs and reputational damage.  [[38]](\n\n* However
column4566: analysts note that this episode looks more like a **short
column4567: intense operational shock** than a multi‑year grounding. Unlike Boeing’s 737 MAX crisis
column4568: regulators have not stopped the A320 family from flying once fixes are verified.  [[39]](\n\nSeveral investor notes also highlight that Airbus reacted **quickly and transparently**
column4569: coordinating closely with EASA and airlines rather than disputing or downplaying the issue – a factor that may limit long‑term damage to the brand.\n\n* The A320 family recently **overtook the Boeing 737 as the industry’s most‑delivered jet**
column4570: cementing Airbus’s dominance in single‑aisle orders.  [[40]](\n\n* Any prolonged perception of software fragility could give Boeing a narrative opening – but only if Airbus’s fix falters
column4571:
which there’s no evidence of so far.

Analysts are split: some see the incident as a **manageable stumble** in an otherwise strong program; others think it underscores the risks of ever more complex avionics in an era of rising solar activity and digital dependency.  [[41]](

* Detailed investigation reports from **EASA
column4572: the US NTSB and other authorities** on the JetBlue incident and the broader fleet risk.  [[42]](\n\n* Potential **refinements to certification standards** for flight‑critical software
column4573:
especially around resilience to **single‑event upsets** and extreme solar weather.  [[43]](

* Additional **service bulletins** from Airbus as it implements permanent software redesigns beyond the emergency rollback deployed this weekend.  [[44]](

This episode is also a timely reminder that commercial aviation doesn’t operate in a vacuum – it operates under the Sun
column4574: during a period of heightened solar activity:\n\n* We are currently near the **peak of Solar Cycle 25**
column4575: when solar flares and coronal mass ejections are more common
column4576: increasing radiation exposure at flight altitudes.  [[45]](\n\n* As aircraft become more software‑defined and interconnected
column4578: redundancy and error‑correction** will only grow in importance for avionics design.\n\nIn that sense
column4579: the A320 recall may prove to be a **wake‑up call rather than a catastrophe**: a costly
column4581: widely trusted aircraft families must constantly be retested against new edge‑cases in our increasingly digital
column4583: sky.\n\n* **Check your flight status** regularly over the next few days
column4584: especially with airlines that are heavy A320 operators.\n\n* If your flight is cancelled due to aircraft availability
column4585: you’re generally entitled to **rebooking or a refund**
column4587:
compensation – check your local rules.  [[46]](

* There is currently **no indication** that fixed aircraft are unsafe; the recall exists precisely to ensure that only compliant jets are flying.

For now
column4588: the story of the A320 software glitch is less “global aviation shutdown” and more “high‑stakes weekend sprint” – with thousands of engineers quietly winning the race against a rare
column4589:
solar‑powered bug before most travelers ever noticed.

## The championship fight will go down to the final race of the season in Abu Dhabi – with three drivers still in contention

[Share on Facebook](  [Share on Twitter]( Qatar GP: Five quick takeaways&via=motorsport)  [Share on WhatsApp](  [Share on Linkedin](  [Share on Pinterest]( Qatar GP: Five quick takeaways)  [Share on Viber](viber://forward?text=

The championship battle goes on.

[Lando Norris]( arrived in Qatar with an opportunity to clinch the title there and then – and would have been able to do so by simply outscoring [Max Verstappen]( and [Oscar Piastri]( by two points.

Yet that task proved too difficult. Norris struggled to match his team-mate
column4628: and at times it looked as if he was being overly cautious throughout the weekend. Sunday turned out to be particularly challenging for the Briton – and not only because of [McLaren]( strategy error. He lacked pace himself and failed to even reach the podium.\n\nBoth championship rivals not only kept their chances alive but closed the gap
column4629: and Norris’ advantage over Verstappen is now far from comfortable.\n\nThe Dutchman and Red Bull
column4631: capitalised on yet another mistake from rivals to win another race
column4632: already fifth since the summer break.\n\nPiastri’s dreadful run has finally ended – and just at the right moment to keep his championship hopes alive. Having lost a huge lead and slipped behind his team-mate in the standings
column4633: the Australian arrived in Qatar level on points with Verstappen
column4634: who only a couple of months ago was more than 100 behind him.\n\nQatar has always suited Piastri – he has been quick at Losail since his rookie season – and those who expected a comeback were proven right. Piastri was the quicker of the two McLaren drivers throughout the weekend
column4635: and he finally started clawing back the points he lost relative to Norris on Saturday by winning the sprint from pole.\n\nNot so long ago
column4637: Ferrari was in second in the constructors’ championship.\n\nSince then
column4638: the Scuderia’s form has been nothing short of catastrophic. It has scored just 26 points in three grands prix
column4639: as many as Williams.\n\nThe SF-25’s behaviour is bafflingly unpredictable
column4640: which the drivers are far from enjoying
column4641: and that costs a significant amount of performance. But it’s not like the car
column4643: could be a winner anyway.\n\nBoth Charles Leclerc and Lewis Hamilton appeared demoralised when speaking to the media this weekend – a regular occurrence in 2025 as far as the seven-time world champion is concerned
column4644: but it was surprising coming from a resolute optimist like Leclerc.\n\nIn Qatar
column4645: Ferrari got its worst result of the season – excluding its double DNF at Zandvoort – with Leclerc eighth and Hamilton down in 12th. The team is now 43 points down on third-placed Red Bull
column4646: and therefore mathematically assured to finish an underwhelming fourth in the constructors’ championship.\n\nAs [Red Bull Racing]( closes in on deciding the driver line-ups for both of its teams
column4647: [Yuki Tsunoda]( needed a strong weekend in Qatar. Not to continue with Red Bull – that ship has clearly sailed – but to stay on the F1 grid altogether by returning to RB.\n\nThe Japanese driver began the weekend strongly
column4648: narrowly beating team-mate Verstappen by 0.009s to take fifth in sprint qualifying. In doing so
column4649: he became the first driver to out-qualify the Dutchman since [Sergio Perez]( in Azerbaijan last year – in other words
column4651: the confident version of Tsunoda didn’t last long. He performed adequately in the sprint race
column4652: finishing fifth behind Verstappen despite a five-second penalty for exceeding track limits. But later that day
column4654:
he found himself back in familiar territory.

He lapped two and a half tenths slower than in sprint qualifying and was knocked out in Q1 for the third consecutive grand prix – and for the tenth time in 26 sessions since joining Red Bull Racing.

His climb from 15th on the grid to 10th at the chequered flag will surely not suffice
column4655: and he now stands on thinner ice than ever. Will the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix be his last in F1 for the time being?\n\nFor the second time this year
column4656: Formula 1 mandated an additional stop for teams in the race. In Monaco
column4657: a two-stop strategy was called for to try and spice up the action
column4658: while Pirelli implemented a 25-lap cap on tyre stints in Qatar over safety concerns – effectively forcing teams into two stops over the 57-lap race.\n\nIn Monaco
column4659: it caused chaos that was tricky to keep track of and did nothing to improve the racing. In Qatar
column4660: an early safety car forced almost the entire field onto the same strategy – stopping on lap 7 and lap 32 to cover the race distance.\n\nMcLaren was the only team not to stop under the safety car
column4661: and this left its drivers effectively fighting back with one hand tied behind their backs after losing out to Verstappen. The stint cap took out all the unpredictability and left McLaren with no option to hold on in hope of another safety car
column4662: as it might have done on another given race weekend.\n\n[## Qatar GP - Sunday

column4717: How Solar Flares Could Have Corrupted An Airbus Plane - Gizmodo
column4719: \"Airbus recalled thousands of aircraft over the weekend.\n\nAircraft maker Airbus recalled thousands of its A320 family aircraft over the weekend for a software fix
column4720: in what has been described as one of the largest directives ever for the company. In an odd twist
column4721: radiation from the sun appears to play a central role in these events.\n\nThe A320 recently surpassed the Boeing 737 to become the most delivered jetliner in history
column4722:
and the recall caused havoc to varying degrees for airlines all around the world. Airbus CEO [Guillaume Faury]( said that the recalls were “causing significant logistical challenges and delays.” Colombian airline [Avianca]( said that the issue had affected more than 70% of its fleet and that it had to close ticket sales for flights through December 8.

The impact of the recall was less severe stateside. Delta and United reported limited impact on its operations while American Airlines said that all 209 of its aircraft that were impacted had been [issued]( the software fix.

Although American air travel was spared from major disruptions
column4723: the issue was brought to light after an October incident in which an Airbus A320 operated by JetBlue en route from Cancun
column4725: New Jersey suddenly dropped in altitude and had to be rerouted to Tampa
column4726:
Florida for an emergency landing.

Airbus said in a statement on Friday that the recalls were issued because the company found that intense solar radiation could “corrupt data critical to the functioning of flight controls” in its A320s.

More specifically
column4727: according to an [FAA directive]( the JetBlue flight in October experienced a malfunction in its elevator aileron computer (ELAC)
column4728: which is a computer that controls the plane’s pitch or nose angle. Airbus believes that solar flares—intense and concentrated streams of electromagnetic solar radiation—may have corrupted the data and caused the ELAC to malfunction
column4729: suddenly sending the aircraft plunging down.\n\nThe fix for the issue is a relatively quick revert to earlier software before the planes can fly again
column4730: except for some jets that may require a complete hardware replacement.\n\nSolar radiation is a headache for aviation
column4731: and the sun has been acting up recently. Back in September
column4732: researchers shared that the Sun could be entering an [unexpected active stage]( with a gradual uptick in activity since 2008. Just this past month
column4733: the Earth was hit with several violent solar flares
column4734: with the NOAA’s Space Weather Prediction Center flagging two of these flares as capable of triggering widespread radio blackouts.\n\nSpace weather expert Tony Phillips [posited earlier this month]( that giant sunspots had been producing solar flares “for weeks” and that there was “no reason to think this activity will subside.” In a [blog post]( on Sunday
column4735: Phillips said that a particularly massive sunspot was now “turning to face Earth” and that future sun flares would have the capacity to cause geomagnetic disturbances.\n\nThe region has unleashed at least two powerful solar flares in the last 12 hours
column4736: and experts are certain there's more to come.](\"
column4738: Crew Injured After Procedures Not Followed - Marine News Magazine
column4741: Inc.\n\nSafety management system procedures were not effectively implemented when the Spirit of Tasmania I’s second engineer was seriously injured in a fall during engine maintenance earlier this year
column4742: the final report from an Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) investigation confirmed.\n\nThe accident occurred during a routine oil change on one of the ship’s main engine turbochargers
column4743: while it was berthed in Geelong
column4745:
on March 6.

Problems encountered during the work led to the decision to replace the turbocharger’s bearing housing cover plate. This required climbing on and off the engine several times.

While climbing off the engine during the work
column4746: the second engineer fell heavily and sustained a serious knee injury
column4747: which later required surgery.\n\nThe ATSB’s investigation found a standard safe route to access the top of the main engine was not defined or used
column4748: despite access being a regular requirement.\n\n“After working on top of the main engine
column4749: the second engineer walked along its rocker covers before stepping across to the opening in the railing
column4750: slipping off the cover and falling
column4751:
” ATSB Director of Transport Safety Stuart Macleod said.

Macleod also noted the decision to replace the bearing housing cover plate represented a significant change to the scope of the work initially planned.

Despite this significant change in scope
column4752: the existing Job Safety Analysis was not reviewed
column4753: nor was a new prestart safety checklist completed by those conducting the work.\n\n“This was due to perceived time pressure
column4754: and a perception by those involved that the work was low risk. Consequently
column4755: the risk of slips and falls involved in the work was not properly considered.”\n\nMore broadly
column4756: the ATSB’s investigation identified Spirit of Tasmania I’s safety management system procedure for Job Safety Analyses (JSAs) was not effectively implemented at the time of the occurrence.\n\n“This meant the JSA for replacing the main engine turbocharger bearing housing cover plate was not in place
column4757: and JSAs covering other work on top of the engine did not address the risks involved in accessing the work site

column5023: \"China’s factory activity contracted for the eighth straight month in November

column5026: according to an official survey on Sunday
column5027: underscoring challenges for the country’s economy despite the U.S.-China trade truce.\n\nThe official manufacturing purchasing managers index rose slightly to 49.2 in November from 49 in October
column5028: China’s National Bureau of Statistics said.\n\nThe PMI is measured on a scale between 0 and 100
column5029: with a reading below 50 indicating contraction. The contraction was in line with analyst expectations.\n\nA U.S. tariff cut earlier this month likely would mean that Chinese exports could gain competitiveness in the U.S. market
column5030: but it may be too early to say whether exports have regained momentum following the trade truce.\n\nU.S. President Donald Trump said the U.S. would cut its tariffs on Chinese goods after meeting Chinese leader Xi Jinping in South Korea on Oct. 30
column5031: raising some optimism over Chinese exports and manufacturing.\n\nA prolonged slump in China’s property market and falling home prices are still hurting consumer confidence
column5032: and real estate investments have been down. Intense price competition domestically in many sectors including the auto industry have also put pressure on many businesses.\n\nMore government policy support is required to help boost the economy
column5033: economists said.\n\nBut “policymakers appear to be delaying further policy support
column5035: chief economist for Greater China at ING bank
column5036: wrote in a note earlier this month.\n\nWhile Chinese authorities previously rolled out measures such as trade-in subsidies for home appliances and electric vehicles
column5037: some of these subsidies are set to be phased out
column5038: and sales and demand are likely to drop
column5039: analysts said.\n\nThe fading boost from the consumer goods trade-in policies may be weighing on domestic demand for manufactured goods and “signals on domestic demand have been mixed
column5042:
last week.

Chinese officials have set a target of around 5% economic growth for the whole of 2025. The economy expanded 4.8% in the July-September quarter.

column5079: Here's What Tesla's New Range of Affordable Electric Cars Cost - CNET
column5081: \"What you get with the stripped-down Model Y and Model 3.\n\nTesla has launched a range of more affordable [electric cars](/home/electric-vehicles/best-ev-electric-car/) -- stripped-back versions of the [refreshed Model Y](/home/electric-vehicles/teslas-model-y-redesign-has-arrived-but-maybe-not-where-you-are/) and [Model 3](/home/electric-vehicles/tesla-model-3-refreshed-with-new-look-longer-range/). These pared-down EVs lower the starting cost
column5082: making it easier for more people to own a Tesla.\n\nThis change is long overdue. As someone who's spent plenty of time behind the wheel of both cars
column5083: I see it as a move that could significantly boost Tesla ownership.\n\nThe idea is simple: Make the same design and driving experience accessible to more people by eliminating the extras that most owners rarely use. In my view
column5084: that's a smart move.\n\nIt comes at a time when electric vehicle shoppers will be seeking more affordable options. According to June figures from [Kelley Blue Book]( the average new vehicle transaction price in the US sits at $49
column5087: 245 on average. That's lower than the market peak in December 2023
column5089: 500 higher than five years ago.\n\n## How much do Tesla's cheaper cars cost
column5090: and what do they come with?\n\nThe Model Y Standard Rear-Wheel Drive starts at $39
column5091: 990 and delivers an EPA-estimated range of 321 miles
column5092: a 0-60 mph time of 6.8 seconds and a peak charging rate of 225 kW. It's powered by a 69 kWh battery and produces about 300 horsepower. This version uses one fewer battery module than the higher trims and is 5% more efficient than the Model Y RWD.\n\nInside
column5093: it features an open-concept center console similar to the Cybertruck
column5094: as well as textile doors and dashboard trim. The 10-way driver and four-way passenger seat controls are now managed via the touchscreen
column5095: eliminating the need for physical buttons.\n\nTesla includes a seven-speaker audio system
column5096: auto high beams and dual-tone textile and vegan leather seats
column5097: but most of the cabin adjustments are manual. That includes the seats
column5098: steering wheel and mirrors. The front seats are heated
column5099:
while the rear ones are not.

The rear passenger screen has been removed

column5104: with 19-inch wheels available as an optional upgrade
column5105: and offers 75 cubic feet of cargo space. Towing capacity is 3
column5108: 061 pounds. It supports Tesla's well-established Supercharging network and can add up to 160 miles in about 15 minutes. This version is available in three colors: stealth gray
column5109: pearl multicoat white and diamond black.\n\nMeanwhile
column5110: the Model 3 Standard Rear-Wheel Drive now starts at $36
column5111: 990 and shares many of the same hardware and software characteristics. It has the same 69 kWh battery
column5112: delivers 321 miles of EPA range and accelerates from 0 to 60 mph in 5.8 seconds thanks to 286 horsepower.\n\nTesla has added a front bumper camera with a washer like the Model Y
column5113: uses vegan leather and textile seating and has touchscreen-controlled seat adjustments instead of physical switches. There are manual second-row folding seats
column5114: a manual-adjust steering wheel and mirrors and no rear heated seats or ventilation.\n\nIt retains the glass panoramic roof but has acoustic front door glass and tempered rear glass. The rear screen has been removed
column5115: and the center console now features uncovered cupholders. It also features a 7-speaker audio setup and the same 15.4-inch touchscreen that dominates the interior.\n\nCharging speeds are identical at up to 225 kW
column5116: and Tesla claims up to 170 miles of range can be added in 15 minutes. It weighs 3

column5118: ditch the LED strips in favor of footwell and door-pocket ambient lighting only
column5119: and come with standard LED headlights with auto adaptive high beams (no matrix LEDs). Interestingly
column5121: although they come with traffic-aware cruise control as standard.\n\n[Full Self-Driving]( is optional
column5123: 000 or via a $99 monthly subscription. Tesla is offering the same four trim levels for each model: Standard
column5125: Premium AWD and Performance.\n\nI think this new approach makes a lot of sense for Tesla. Instead of chasing the luxury end of the market
column5126: this brings the focus back to what originally made the brand so popular: offering long-range
column5128: affordable electric vehicles that still feel cutting-edge. By trimming back on extras
column5129: the company has created an option that could appeal to first-time EV buyers who might otherwise look at cheaper rivals.\n\nIn my experience
column5130: Tesla's biggest strength has always been its software and driving dynamics
column5131: and those remain intact here. For anyone on the fence about making the switch to an EV
column5132: these new versions of the Model 3 and Model Y could be the most convincing reason yet.\n\nPricing for the Model Y Standard starts at $39
